147382747.review:
En primer lugar, la narrativa del juego ha sido ampliamente elogiada. La historia sigue a Abe, un esclavo Mudokon que se embarca en una misión para liberar a su gente de la explotación de una corporación malévola. La trama se desarrolla en el mundo oscuro y surrealista de Oddworld, y ha sido apreciada por su originalidad y profundidad. Los temas de la esclavitud y la liberación proporcionan una base emocionalmente resonante para la historia.

Además, los gráficos y el diseño artístico han sido puntos destacados en las críticas. El juego presenta un estilo visual distintivo y detallado que ha envejecido sorprendentemente bien. Los entornos y personajes están ricamente diseñados, lo que crea una atmósfera inmersiva en el mundo de Oddworld.

El juego también ha sido elogiado por su jugabilidad desafiante. Los jugadores deben resolver rompecabezas, evitar trampas y enfrentar enemigos mientras guían a Abe a través de varios niveles. La necesidad de estrategia y habilidad ha sido considerada como uno de los aspectos más gratificantes del juego.

Sin embargo, algunas críticas han señalado que la curva de dificultad puede ser empinada en ciertos puntos del juego, lo que puede resultar frustrante para algunos jugadores. Además, los controles precisos son esenciales para superar algunos de los desafíos del juego, lo que puede ser un obstáculo para algunos jugadores.

I'm going to be honest, I bought this game for the nostalgia. In my youth this game was way ahead of its time. This and Abe's Exodus were two of my favorite games to play way back then. The game play is still as fun, quirky, and frustratingly  imprecise (part of its charm) as I remember. 

I can get over the dated graphics. What I can't get past are the cut scenes. Not only are they incredibly slow, they don't even play like movies anymore. They're more like a slow waterfall of still frames that go on for far too long. I'm also not going to download some third party app and/or mess with the game files in an attempt to fix the issue. It just doesn't run well on modern systems and Oddworld Inhabitants should have done their due diligence to make sure these games would run well on modern equipment and update the control scheme. It's not worth the three dollars to tarnish the memory of this wonderfully strange classic. Either find a way to play the original or let it be a fond memory.

142611881.review:
I beat this game and the sequel (Exodus) when I was a kid, my friend borrowed it to me and I was hooked on it.

Playing now as an adult I can say that this game is freaking difficult at times and only now I realise that this is a puzzle game where if you get something wrong, either you or you kinsmen die a brutal death.

The game is mean in the sense that there are secrets and the secrets are really not in places you would expect and when you do find them, they're even more difficult than the main area.

I mean, the first secret as right at the beginning of the game which I'm sure 90% of players have missed.

Now, the grand reveal, do I recommend this game?
To answer that question, let me ask you a different question - are you masochistic? If yes, then there is your answer.
Do you strive for perfection in 100%ing (or 99%ing in this case) a game? Then this game will be a challenge for you.

I suggest playing the game on your own and try to find all the secrets, then when you're done, you can go again and watch a tutorial or read up on where the secrets are.
The secrets contain extra of your fellow priso- I mean fellow workers which you have to set free in order to get all 99 of them out.

Just a heads up, this is an older game (1997) and try to remember to save whenever you can as the game has checkpoints, they can be really far apart at times. So when you enter a special area later within the main area, if you die you have to go back to the beginning of the main area to which you came.

All in all, the game is a big, brutal puzzle which can be frustrating at times, so don't get too angry if things don't go your way even after the 5th, 10th or 20th attempt.
If you're frustrated, pause the game, it's not going anywhere, calm down for a minute and come back to it with a new strategy.
Remember, you're here to have fun torturing yourself, but don't go overboard with it.

Oh and some areas can have bugs if you come back to them.

142273837.review:
As a disclaimer, I understand that Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee holds a special place in the hearts of many fans, but for those unfamiliar with the game or who prefer modern gaming experiences, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend it. Here's my honest assessment, highlighting the game's outdated graphics and cumbersome controls.

Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee was released quite a while ago, and unfortunately, time has not been kind to its graphics. The visual quality is noticeably dated, with pixelated character models and environments lacking the detail we have come to expect in modern games. While it's important to appreciate the game's historical significance, it may be a significant hurdle for newcomers looking for a visually immersive experience.

One of the major downsides of playing Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee today is the wonky controls. Compared to contemporary games, the control scheme feels clunky and unrefined. Maneuvering Abe can be a frustrating experience, as the character's movements feel imprecise and often unresponsive. This lack of fluidity can lead to unnecessary deaths and repetitive trial-and-error gameplay that may quickly sour the overall experience.

In the end, unless you are a die-hard fan seeking a nostalgic trip down memory lane, I would caution against picking up Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee. Its outdated graphics and cumbersome controls make it a tough sell for those accustomed to modern gaming conveniences. However, if you can overlook these shortcomings and appreciate the game for its historical significance, you might find some enjoyment in its unique world and gameplay mechanics.

139340094.review:
I'll just write it, I've replayed this game enough times over the years.

Like Abe's Exoddus, an in my opinion refined sequel to this excellent puzzle platformer, Abe's Oddysee is about exploring a weird, messed up world. This and that actually have pretty distinct art styles, mostly because each game has a wide array of locales.

This game I think they had a smaller team and probably didn't have the art process down perfect yet, so some of the backgrounds and screens in Oddysee feel at times a bit lacking in detail. It's not really a huge problem though, since I still find the game pretty visually stimulating and pleasant to look at. RuptureFarms in particular really stands out I think as like a steel mill meat processing nightmare with highly OSHA non-compliant hardware and machinery.

But anyway, aside from the graphics which I maintain are pretty stunning still to this day, I think the running and jumping gameplay in this one is very very good. Abe has his momentum in canned animation form, and part of getting good at the game is just adapting to the delay in pretty much everything he does. 

In some games, this I think would be a detriment, it doesn't really bother me in Abe's Oddysee however because half the battle is figuring out what you're meant to do, and executing it tends to not be all that difficult once you are comfortable enough with the controls.

Anyway, running and jumping aside, most of the stuff you do basically changes from zone to zone, the opening in RuptureFarms you're aiming simply to escape, and if you can liberate some friends along the way, all the better. You touch bombs to turn them on or more frequently off, you pick up bombs and throw them at people, you possess sligs and make them shoot each other up, and you avoid all of the numerous hazards to the best of your ability along the way (especially pits which will probably be like half your total deaths).

The game is challenging, even without the controls being a little difficult. Sligs for instance will pause sometimes for almost exactly the amount of time you need to cross a gap, moving from shadow to shadow. When you walk on screen, and enemies start moving, sometimes you only have a second or two to figure out what you're looking at and how to react, so dying is not an infrequent thing. 

Fortunately, this game and the sequel both give you infinite lives and continues, so you never really need to worry about not being able to progress, and dying can reset a situation if it develops out of your control (i.e. too many sligs are awake in the next room or something) or if on a rare occasion you find yourself softlocked (which is rare but can happen).

Unfortunately, Abe's Oddysee has full control over the checkpoint system, and you can only checkpoint yourself a couple of times per level! The save system also only returns you to the last checkpoint you reached, so unlike Exoddus, clearing an extremely difficult part can mean sometimes, you might have to do another immediately after, without a checkpoint, and that can be rough.

So really, I'd say this one is even harder than the sequel, since in that one you have 'quiksaves' and so on.

Overall though, it's just a blast from start to finish, even though the checkpoint thing can get a bit frustrating or tedious at times. And if you're not feeling it, maybe pick up Exoddus instead, which is my personal favourite between the two.

137440335.review:
I was torn on whether to give Abe's Oddysee a thumbs up or thumbs down because neither really feels fitting.
Ultimately decided to go with a thumbs down because I think the best part of the game is everything [i]other than the gameplay[/i], which in turn just isn't enjoyable.
When I'd sooner recommend a friend to watch someone else play it than to play it himself, there is a problem.

Let's get into the details though, as there is a lot to criticize. 

The visual design, music, sound effects, alien atmosphere - all magnificent.
Gameplay though, as I read someone else describe it: a [i]sloppy[/i] game that expects YOU to be perfect.
Save system is stupid, controls sometimes aren't responsive or bug out in the worst possible moment, so even if you [i]are[/i] in fact perfect, every now and then you're forced to bite the bullet and overdo a section because game rng decided to just not cooperate and a single error usually means starting again from the last savepoint.

The modokons you save are drooling idiots. I'll forgive them not being smart enough to jump or roll, but they always require a "hello! -> follow me!", which by itself is fine, but there are sections where time (and timing) is REALLY of the essence. And in the middle of it a modokon is likely to stop following you because he had to stand still for three seconds and he'd rather literally die than wait more than that. Thanks friend.

The difficulty is all over the place, too. Halfway point felt like a tempting moment to drop the game. I figured that if it's been this rage-inducing up to this point, I can only imagine what awaits onwards.
But as it turned out, the second half of the game was overall [i]easier[/i], less rich in artificial difficulty, felt more consistent, gave more feedback on your progress, and was oddly swimming in grenades which often could provide alternative solutions to problems. It also had no secret areas, which are generally the hardest part of the game, because 1) you have to find them in the first place, 2) they tend to be the most unfair sections and 3) there often isn't a savepoint after them, so even on success you end up replaying them a lot.
And for some reason, all of them were shoved into the first half of the game? Bizarre.

Hardest section of the game is arguably the second quarter, after you [spoiler]escape Rupture Farms and before you return to it. Particularly the wildlife trials you're being put through by your tribe to prepare for rescuing modokans from the evil meat plant. Makes me think that you know guys, this could have been much easier and less prone to failure if instead of putting me trough the tests you'd just let me handle the rescuing uninterrupted.[/spoiler]

[b]TL;DR:[/b]
[b]+[/b] good and unique visuals
[b]+[/b] quality music and sound effects
[b]+[/b] atmospheric
[b]-[/b] jank savepoint system from hell
[b]-[/b] questionable responsiveness of controls and movement
[b]-[/b] difficulty that more often than not feels artificial and not "fair"

[b]EDIT:[/b]
To elaborate on my gripe with the save system, and what makes me call it jank,

when you get past a savepoint, there's a visual indication that it was in fact savepoint, and you usually notice it, but it's subtle enough that sometimes in the heat of things you might miss it and be unsure if the last save was a moment ago, or a long time ago. There is manual saving, but the way it works it reloads you to the last successful savepoint.

The best way to describe how it's jank is to imagine savepoints are one-time use. After that, a savepoint spot is inactive, and only becomes active again if you traverse to a later/earlier savepoint - then that previously inactive savepoint spot becomes active again if you go back to it. Consequentially, it causes a lot of annoying backtracking back-and-forth between savepoints just to be sure progress is saved.
It didn't work like that 100% of the time for whatever reason, but the best way to make it work consistently for you is to assume that's the case.

Problem is, some sections do not [i]have[/i] more than 1 savepoint, so it basically forces you to complete a few sequences perfectly with no way to save progress in between because if you die, you have to redo the whole series of sequences again. Some of the hardest hidden areas liked to be placed in the middle of those.

It wasn't consistent though, in the sense that those multiple-sequences-per-savepoint weren't reserved for the later areas, and if anything most (if not all) of them were present in the first half of the game. Feels like the savepoint [i]system[/i] and savepoint [i]placement[/i] was designed by two different people, and they never talked to each other.

125618801.review:
Cancerous save mechanic:
-ignores the progress and spot at which you actually saved
-only allows a single save
-happily saves when you don't want it to save (skipped area, people died) because it saves after you made progress and overwrites your save then
-"save" merely means it doesn't remember your position and progress for the current section but just the spot and progress as when you start into the current section, so it's not really a save but rather a checkpoint-like thing, which is deceiving; THIS forces you to replay the entire section all over again once anything goes wrong and is by far the worst design decision possible, as it makes the game annoyingly repetitive because usually there's a damn good reason to be stuck at a certain spot and it's just not fun having to re-do all the repetitive things all over again each time, it's just annoying, bad design, the reason why I'm tossing this into the corner to never be looked at again after it already got it's 3rd (and final) chance to actually be a game (= entertaining instead of repetitive in a robot-like way to get to the one point that matters), but failed.

The controls react delayed:
-if you press the right button before the animation for the previous action is completed if will count as if you hadn't pressed the right button at all
-likewise when you want an ally to follow or stop there's quite a delay before that gets executed, eventually resulting in them getting killed, forcing you to restart all over again

The story is nice, they put some effort into the presentation, the gameplay is okay but the save feature single-handedly kills this game for me. If I had to design its game box there'd be a warning label on it, stating: "WARNING: Uses a checkpoint mechanic that'll force you to do an entire section all over again each time something goes wrong and may also save your progress against your will on skipped areas and lost people that you were supposed to save."
Can't honestly recommend this to anyone, not because it's dated, but because there's a huge issue with its save mechanic.

Just before ending this I looked at a youtube video with perfect gameplay: Turns out that right at the start of the game there are already several secret areas where you can miss stuff before the tutorial even starts and explains the mechanics and how to work with them. I also discovered by this that you can chant to control enemies and kill them and while controlled use them to kill other enemies. WELL THAT'D HAVE BEEN HELPFUL TO KNOW BEFORE ! Thankfully the tutorial didn't teach me. The game really tries to be the worst possible.

124873073.review:
This game kicks some serious ass!


About This Port: 

I've seen some reviews that say the game should be in its original resolution, but personally as someone who played the game on PS1 (and played this version on a wider screen) I don't mind at all. 

You can play with keyboard or controller and you can re-map the buttons to suit how you want to play (although I've heard some people cant get their controllers to bind properly, I'm using a USB Controller and it's worked perfectly fine for me).

The game runs smoothly (on my PC, it might differ between Computers and Laptops).

Cutscenes are still compressed, smooth and beautiful (For me at least, they might be more choppy and frame by second depending on your system).

About OddWorld Abe's Oddysee itself:

Abe is such a lovable, goofy and well-designed character.

Environments and backgrounds can range from many different colours and lighting and just be aesthetically pleasing to the eye.

The story is interesting, entertaining and at times dark.

Abe's Oddysee doesn't do autosave so do remember to save your game before you get off otherwise you'll have to play parts of the game again. I've encountered a glitch while dying where my screen just went completely black and I couldn't do anything except restarting the game, so save the game regularly while playing just in case.

The game is tough as nails and not easy, whether you're trying to save all the Mudokons or not. You'll die and die repeatedly to things you swear are impossible to do and keep replaying the same part (depending on how good you are). 

What? Can't do it? Game too hard? Too bad, git gud. 

Overall depending on how powerful you computer or laptop is, your experience of this game will play differently but I've had a blast revisiting this classic title and can't wait to play the steam port for Abe's Exxodus.

122474915.review:
[u][b]AMAZING GAME, BAD PORT[/b][/u]

First off, this port has many issues, too numerous to list here. I heavily recommend this title, but you should either play using the R.E.L.I.V.E engine, with which you will have native gamepad support and don't have to deal with most of these bugs, or the Playstation version which has slightly lower quality backgrounds and sprites but better effects. Currently with R.E.L.I.V.E you will still encounter some minor problems (I will list these later), however the R.E.L.I.V.E project plans on fixing these remaining issues eventually. It can't be overstated how much R.E.L.I.V.E improves this port, I consider it a crucial install if you plan on playing the PC version.

Abe's Oddysee is an cinematic action adventure puzzle platformer. Trial and error, experimentation, and precision are primary aspects of the gameplay loop. Death is part of the process here; accept this and you have a great time on your hands. If this does not sound fun to you then you probably won't like this game. 

Soaked in atmosphere, and dense with content and challenge, it is an unforgettable journey that everyone deserves to experience at least once in their lives. As an escaped slave turned savior, the future of your species and others rest on your shoulders. Industrialists control and consume the continent of Mudos, escape your fate as a popsicle and enact revenge.

When working properly, Abe's Oddysee has very responsive and accurate controls. Coming from traditional platformers, you may feel the controls to be stiff or clunky, I believe this is mainly due to character movements taking place on a grid. Once you get used to this concept gameplay will feel much smoother and you will have complete control of your character. There is little to no input buffer here, you input the action exactly when you want it to happen. The result of this is a dependable sandbox of environments and characters that encourages player expression and creative thinking.

I heavily recommend you find the time to experience this masterwork. Even now, but especially for its time, Abe's Oddysee explores new territory showing just what a video game can be, pushing the limits of game design to be something truly unique. While New N' Tasty is not a bad remake, in my opinion it does not live up to the originals, especially when it comes to the gameplay and art direction.

If you choose to play using R.E.L.I.V.E these are the bugs from the port you currently may encounter and how to deal with them:

-Droning sound effect. Sometimes something like a portal sound will get "stuck" and continuously loop rather annoying, this is fixed by simply pausing and unpausing

-Broken Toggle Mine. Sometimes the button on the UXB mines will stop working, restart the game to fix this issue.

-Crashes. Though crashes are much less common, they still happen, and while rare it can happen right at the end of a difficult level, so be aware of that possibility. This may sound like a super bad thing, but really is is not that bad, by the time you get to harder parts of the game you will be so skilled that redoing one section will mean nothing to you. If this is a deal breaker for you, play the Playstation version.

110750916.review:
Frankly its an infuriating game that'll play you the classic song and dance of death repeatedly over very tiny mistakes, and while this game's loop is distinguished from other retro difficulty platformers by decently frequent checkpoints, oddworld doesn't shy away from getting you to repeat lengthy sections and puzzles repeatedly, making ample use of your time, of course having said this i want to clarify that i mean this in an appreciative fashion.

Oddworld abe's oddyssey isn't a very profound game, its themes of slavery, extinction and environmentalism hint to a depressing story as supported by its depiction of a bleak and defected world, but its a facade counterbalanced by slapstick humor and characters playing simon says via farts, most subjects it looks at it merely glances at to the effect of laughs, which makes the story, with any of its multiple endings rich in its own right, but nowhere near as fleshed out as someone like Lorne Lanning will lead you to believe.

That said its a very moody experience overall. Sure you'll often play sections with chases and self destruct sequences but most of the time you're sneaking around, hiding in shadows and moving carefully, inching towards guards and wild beasts, breathing right under their neck all the while guiding your racially motivated minions to salvation.
It sure is a fair bit more stressful than most other kids games, yet at the same time it offers moments of relief, where the farther away from civilization you find yourself in the more breathing room you're given to work around with. Its really around the middle part of the game where oddworld comes into its own, with visuals and music that simply can't be replicated, not even by any of its, admitedly more fun sequels...

Its really a unique and imaginative game about starving smurf shamans that ride on camels who hex middle class workers for their horrid dietary habits and i've always thought its pretty cool. Its a criminally cheap and great introduction to the fairly abandoned subgenre of cinematic platformers so give it a try and feel free to neglect the existence of oddworld soulstorm in the process.

103030162.review:
I'm very hot and cold on this game, especially since there's a remake of it. 

	The original is typically recommended due to the superior art style. The original artists added touches to the pre-rendered environments post processing, giving everything this gritty, industrial look. It's lacking in the remake (everything looks too clean), and detracts from the message of environmental degredation. If you can get past the hard-coded low resolution, the original game still has a charm to it that the remake lacks.

	The game itself is a puzzle platformer. The puzzles are fantastic, making use of environmental hazards and enemy types. Everything is slowly introduced and made full use of. There are quirky features, such as being able to jump between the fore and background. Abe can't do anything beyond a regular human in terms of physicality, making this a slower, but more methodical platformer. There's a lot of trial and error, which actually leads to my next point. 

	Abe's Oddysee's chief sin are the trash controls. Abe will always run through his animation cycles before responding to player input. This means that if you stop pressing left or right, he will stop only after his walking animation does. If you press jump or duck, there is always a delay between the input and the actual action on-screen. There's even an ever so slight "recovery from walking down a ledge" animation, which is disastrous when there is an enemy at the bottom of the ledge that WILL immediately chase you. 

	This wouldn't even be an issue if the game didn't feel the need to become Mario the Hedgehog every once in a while, with speed and precision platforming minus the tight controls. It becomes a game of pressing buttons not when you want to, but when you can visually see (or estimate) based on the animation cycles. Which creates its own issue as you either stopped running too early or too late when something is chasing you. Often, the game just fails to register me pressing 'jump' after falling down a ledge and running for some bizarre reason.

	You can't even excuse this due to age, since platformers over a decade older than this didn't have these issues. If the game had a quick-save feature (typical of PC games at the time), it would go a long way towards alleviating these grievances. The controls would still be an issue, but I could at least retry straight away. Thankfully, the remake (and sequel) implemented quick-saves.

	Frustratingly hard games aren't new to me, but having to simultaneously fight with the controls is. I eventually became proficient enough to look past the control scheme, but I was ocassionally reminded of how stupid it is that Abe controls like he's in a point and click. This is still a fantastic puzzle platformer, but the remake fixes so much. Unless you really value grittier environments, just play the remake. If it didn't exist, I'd [i]probably[/i] give this a thumbs up, cause you [b]WILL[/b] get used to the controls (if you stick with it). But why deal with the frustration?

In my opinion one of the best platform games ever made. 
What I liked:
 - Writing
This game has a great sense of humour and is so imaginative. It is rare to see such original concepts and ideas in a game, even at the time. The entire game satires the modern world and the exploitation of the natural environment.
- Game Mechanics 
As you progress through the game there are various mechanics introduced to the player when needed. The difficulty slowly ramps up the further you get. Unless you know about a few secrets early on. Each puzzle requires at least some trial and error as well as perfect execution in some cases. This keeps the game fun and interesting as you do not just breeze through. Some sequences will leave you sighing with relief once you've made it through. None will leave you so frustrated that you want to quit... well not in my case!
- Artwork
The artwork of the game i.e. the scenery / character and animal design is all unique and fun to look at. Really impressive stuff. The game is nearly as old as me but I can still appreciate the world building.

100180828.review:
The Oddworld series is a unique and iconic franchise of video games created by Oddworld Inhabitants. It is known for its distinctive blend of dark humor, inventive gameplay mechanics, and thought-provoking social commentary. Here's a review of the Oddworld series as a whole, focusing on its most prominent titles:

**Title: Oddworld - A Darkly Humorous and Thought-Provoking Video Game Series**

**Rating: ★★★★☆**

**Pros:**

1. **Unique and Engaging World:** The Oddworld series takes place in a bizarre and darkly comedic universe filled with strange creatures, twisted corporations, and dystopian themes. This unique setting sets the games apart from traditional video game worlds and creates a memorable atmosphere.

2. **Social Commentary:** One of the standout features of Oddworld is its willingness to tackle serious social and environmental issues within its narrative. Themes such as corporate greed, exploitation, and environmental destruction are woven into the storylines, offering players food for thought beyond the gameplay itself.

3. **Inventive Gameplay Mechanics:** The series is known for introducing innovative gameplay mechanics in each installment. Games like "Abe's Oddysee" and "Abe's Exoddus" focus on puzzle-solving and platforming, while "Stranger's Wrath" incorporates a unique combination of first-person shooting and bounty hunting. These diverse mechanics keep the gameplay fresh and engaging.

4. **Dark Humor:** Oddworld games are known for their dark and satirical humor. The witty writing and amusing character interactions provide moments of levity within the otherwise grim and challenging environments. The humor is an integral part of the series' identity.

5. **Character Design:** The character design in Oddworld is both visually striking and memorable. Characters like Abe, Munch, and Stranger have unique appearances and personalities that contribute to the series' charm.

**Cons:**

1. **Difficulty:** Some of the Oddworld games are known for their high level of difficulty, especially when it comes to puzzles and platforming sections. While this can be rewarding for players seeking a challenge, it may frustrate those looking for a more casual gaming experience.

2. **Irregular Release Schedule:** The Oddworld series has seen a somewhat irregular release schedule, with long gaps between major titles. This has left fans waiting for new entries in the series.

3. **Limited Appeal:** The dark and quirky nature of Oddworld may not be to everyone's taste. Some players might find the games' themes and humor off-putting or too unconventional.

In summary, the Oddworld series is a unique and thought-provoking franchise that has carved out its own niche in the world of video games. Its distinctive blend of dark humor, inventive gameplay mechanics, and social commentary sets it apart from other titles in the industry. While some games in the series can be challenging, they offer a rewarding and memorable experience for players who appreciate its unconventional approach. If you're looking for something different in the world of gaming, the Oddworld series is worth exploring for its creativity and willingness to tackle complex themes.

Er... Somewhat entertaining but... This is a puzzle-platformer game. The graphics are pretty old and dark, still kinda charming. The music is decent but repetitive. There's a fun story here. 

Bugs... It might keep running in the background after quitting. Runs on win 7. 

Now the "but". This is retro, really retro. So retro that playing this might be considered homework in some schools for developers. It didn't age well. The port is not very good. It's a hard game, with a lot of precision. That's OK. But you can't save. There are checkpoints, but if you miscalculate somewhere, you'll be forced to repeat a big chunk of the game. This is the old concept of endless repetition till you stop rage-quitting. I personally find the concept primitive and very annoying. It's boring rather than challenging. I do like the dark, absurd humor. It's the bright spot here but the only one. 

This is a very niche game now. Only playable for reasons of nostalgia and/or masochism. I can't recommend this in good conscience to the gaming masses.  I see red.

Well, it looks like my fun blast from the past had to be cut short. There's a bug with this port of the game that can cause one of the Shrykull portals in Zulag 3 to despawn each time you enter the room it's in. I couldn't find any solution to my problem, so I tried reloading the game to my save at the start of Zulag 3, but this port has a bug where saves don't record your progress correctly, so it booted me back to when Abe first returns to Rupture Farms instead. I don't want to go through all of that again just to check and see if the portal's still bugged, so I'm calling it quits on Abe's Oddysee. 

Man, I love this game to death, but don't play this port. In addition to what I wrote above, this port has a lot of other issues to it as well, and you'd be much better off buying the original PS1 release somewhere. The controls can be a bit unresponsive sometimes, which can get you killed when you're in a bind, and even worse is that your button inputs can get confused for other keys. I can't count how many times I've pressed 1 to say "hello" only for Abe to crouch down as if I pressed X. There's also no real gamepad support, which didn't bother me a whole lot since I was able to adjust to the keyboard controls, but I know that can be a real detriment to some players' experiences. Then there's the cutscenes getting scrambled and running at like 12fps for some reason, but that's probably the least impactful issue in my opinion. I was looking forward to finishing this, and playing Exodus too, but I guess that aint happening.

89453601.review:
Not gonna lie this game saved my life. I was... probably 10-12 years old when it was released, and I was trapped in the Rupture Farms of my own life. Very dark times. Abe taught me if you work hard and keep trying, you can break free and it'll eventually get better. Ofc there's also other relevant messages like being good to others is important, living in harmony with nature is mandatory for survival, and greedy megacorporations suck.

I have absolutely nothing bad to say about this game. The gameplay, atmosphere, story, characters and music are just pure perfection. The dark and creepy vibes caught my attention back in the day, and even today it hasn't lost its touch. The remake is good, but like many others have already mentioned, I mourn the atmosphere it no longer has. Seems to be the same problem with many retro remakes I've seen. They seem to be making everything as colourful, comical and cartoony as they possibly can, which is a shame.

Final note: this game is hard. I've beaten it countless times, found all secrets and saved all mudokons. I used to be a goddamn guru when it comes to Abe's Oddysee and Exoddus. And yet it was a complete massacre when I found this on Steam sale and decided to grab it, and tried to play it on PC. Jesus Christ. The PSX controls have been so ingrained into my muscle memory that it's just hopeless to try and proceed with keyboard. Have to try again with a controller, lol.

Played for an hour or so, saved the game at checkpoint and quit. Next time I started playing, it didn't continue from the last checkpoint, but the one before that. This game is golden but devs plz fix them bugs. And peeps, if you have a chance, play this on another platform. Don't let a bad port ruin your experience of this masterpiece.

89201423.review:
DO YOURSELVES A FAVOUR AND DO NOT BUY THE REMAKE. Seriously, buy this one instead. If you can go through its compatibility issues and remap the controls via big pic mode, you will find out that is game is superior in every way. The game's artstyle, which was criminally butchered in the Remake, is a testamet to the talent of the developers. Set in a dark and opressive alien world, Abe is a slave worker that has to escape the meat factory, survive against deadly aliens and save his fellow slave Mudokons along the way.

Controlling Abe feels realistic. He needs momentum to jump, and almost every failed stunt will result in his death. The only problem I had is some times the controls can be unresponsive. It rarely happens though, so its not a big issue. Other than his athleticism, Abe can possess certain kind of enemies, or distract others with his chant. Abe has voice commands that allow him to give orders to other Mudokons and solve voice puzzles. You must to be careful when giving commands though or the Mudokons you control might die. You need at least 50 Mudokons saved in order to unlock the good ending. There are plenty to be found around during your playthrough, but lots of them are well hidden so you need to keep your eyes open for secret passages. 

If you enjoy challenging platformers, this gem is a must play.

85843792.review:
Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is a fine game, kind of a mixed bag of good and bad. On the one hand, it absolutely oozes charm and character, and has an genuine atmosphere that most triple-A games these days would kill to have. On the other hand, this is a 20+ year-old game, and it definitely feels like it. However, all that isn't necessarily a good or bad thing, but a mix of both. Here's the good and the bad as I felt it:

The Good:

-The game has a great story. Simple, but you instantly feel a connection with the hapless and helpless Abe. Multiple endings also add a layer of challenge and re-playblility.

-The game is challenging, well-built, and requires a lot of experimentation to solve the puzzles. It's not a puzzle game per se, but it's more puzzle game than a side-scroller. There are parts of the game completed just by your cunning and wit, while other sections will require quick reflexes and laser-sharp button presses.

-The artwork and visuals are just fantastic. Sure, this game came out in '97, and it sure looks like it, yet it holds a certain charm for anyone who grew up playing games in this era. It evens looks cool to new-comers unfamiliar with such a style.

Now, The Bad:

-This game is HARD. That alone wouldn't be enough to warrant a mark, but there aren't an ample amount of modern guides for this game, and trust me, you aren't getting through this 100% without a guide, at least not in a reasonable amount of time. If you do look for a guide, get used to using a website built in 1998 that's just green text on a black background. There are also secrets you will probably miss, and that can be frustrating if you're trying to beat it without a guide holding your hand. Just know that subsequent play-throughs will be significantly less frustrating, if not really any easier.

-The game suffers from being built in the 90s, without the modern things like quicksave or snappier controls. The game may crash on you, causing hours of loss of progress. Audio glitches are also common, though they're only mostly distracting rather than "game-breaking." The game will feel a certain way because it was limited by the technology that existed at the time.

-Lastly, the game is not the easiest to learn. Pay close attention to the tutorials or look up a guide, or start the game completely over mid-way through. Most of the games core mechanics are explained in the first couple of hours, so restarting after that could make the whole experience replayed so much better.

In conclusion, I definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging, nostalgia-inducing puzzle/side-scroller hybrid that contains a lot of personality and charm, which also has several sequels and an PS5/PC sequel on the way. Just keep a guide handy and don't give up!

83519460.review:
I had never played an oddworld game before this, but I was always interested in doing so. I can now say that this is a fantastic game that is rich in atmosphere and charm.

 The gameplay relies on precision, and it is a joy to obtain the skills necessary to beat this game. The whole goal of the game is to save as many of your fellow mudokkens (that's the name for Abe's race, who are being kept in Rupture Farms as slave workers) as you can, and ultimately take out the head honcho who runs Rupture Farms. The mechanic that allows you to communicate with other characters (which you will be using a lot) is fun to use and varies depending on whether you're talking as a Mudokken or as a Slig. What's a Slig, you ask? They are one of the main enemies that you will be facing, and this game features a really cool mechanic where you can possess them and control them. It's always a great moment when you get to take control of a Slig and mow down their own kind using a machine gun. That was kind of a fucked up sentence but I'm leaving it in.

 If you're into the whole cinematic platformer, prince of persia-esque, kind of thing, this is the game for you. There are some very difficult parts, and at times the save locations can be annoying as failure means you might be sent back a good amount. Regardless, the game is really cool and really fun, and I think it holds up great today. And the good news is, the sequel to this game, Abe's Exodus, is even better.

Terrible port of an amazing game

I loved the original on PS1, but playing this is painful at times - the inputs don't feel direct, it's like you are telling someone what you want to do, and they are telling someone else to do it, and often things get lost in translation.
For example, often inputs are just missed or duplicated and sometimes instead of saying 'Follow Me' you jump forward. This suggests they have combined two button pushes on the PS1 version into a single button on your PC keyboard, and the code they have used to do this is terrible.

Considering this is a game that relies on precision, this is very disappointing. You are probably better off just getting an emulator.

77901432.review:
Quick:

0/5.  Nostalgia can play a big part in the decision to purchase a game.  Twenty year old memories of simpler days may offer comfort, and familiarity is welcome in irritable and uncertain times.  Memories of sitting in front of my Sony PlayStation, over twenty years ago, and experiencing this game for the first time are half of the reason that I purchased Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee on Steam.  The other half of that reason, is the high regard in which others still hold this game.  Technological advancements aside, as a game standing on its own merits... this one does not hold up.  Playing Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee was an annoying chore.  The controls / character's responsiveness are unbelievably bad.  This is my main gripe with this game.  Joining that problem, is the bad design choices that are littered throughout the experience.  In the days of yore, games were intentionally made more difficult to ensure that people who rented the game wouldn't beat it the first time that they rented it.  Undoubtedly this decision has tainted many games and damned them to being less than they otherwise would be.  It is almost certainly the case here.

More:

I cannot recall being as frustrated as I was playing Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee, during any other play-through of any other game.  There is almost no comparison.  The suppressed rage is far beyond what I could have imagined when I made this purchase.  This is not a difficult game, it is a stupid one.  If I had a nickel for every-time that Abe ran off of the edge of a cliff, after I heard my keyboard's space key 'click' while his feet were still on the ground... I might have a lot of nickels.  I cannot confirm that I always pressed it while the character was still grounded, but I am almost certain that I did the vast majority of the time.  If I did not... then I would need some sort of explanation for my performance in every-other modern platformer that I have played in contrast to this one... and I'm not even that good at platformers.  The difference in performance is that bad.  Fluid animation seems to have been prioritized over Abe's responsiveness to button presses.  I've noticed that several actions in the game do not register unless an animation that is in progress has finished.  It is much more likely (at least to me) that this is the cause of the lack of control... rather than my sudden and suspiciously specific late button-presses.

Another gripe of mine is in the level / puzzle design.  How irritating is it?  Very irritating.  No... it's just stupid.  Think about Mario Bros.  Why does Mario Bros. not have a pit at the end of the level?  Why is there no death pit that Mario can fall into if he jumps over the flag?  It's not there because that would be a choice only a fool would make.  Even a child would have  enough intuition to know better.  Sadly, I cannot say the same for the designers of this game.  Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee should be the focal point of study in a class on how not to design a game.  I hate this game and everything that it stands for.  Oh, and by the way, if you don't save enough of your ugly blue mud-donkey brethren by the end of the game, then you get the bad ending and are expected to try again.  I say 'nay-nay'.  And I don't care about not spoiling the game in this review.

They say where there's smoke, there's fire.  If Oddworld Inhabitant's (the developers of this trash's) resume of games is anything to go by, then there's a roaring blaze at their headquarters (if it still exists).  It looks like this one IP has been carrying that studio since it's inception, and I think I know why.  It would appear they got lucky with the success of the Sony PlayStation, and managed to craft an inexplicably loved protagonist that they have ironically enslaved to their mediocre development team.  But... who knows really.  It does appear that way, though.  I would have to play more of their games to know the truth.  That will not happen.  I bought this game, and Oddworld: Abe's Exodus at the same time.  I have uninstalled them both, and deleted the associated videos from my YouTube channel.  I have willingly flushed a few bucks, and roughly 24 hours of my time playing the game and editing the videos down the drain.  I refuse to further acknowledge, or promote this game in any way.  I would give up another 24 hours just to erase the memory of playing this garbage from my mind.  My suggestion is that you do not buy this game.  If you're a sadist, and you need your fix... find another way that doesn't encourage these people to make more games.  Do it for me.

I would recommend Abe's Oddysee, but with some qualification. For a modern gamer with no nostalgia for this series or era of games, you'd probably be better served by skipping over this one and going straight for New 'n' Tasty. For those that are tuned to the wavelength of late 90s gaming, then Abe's Oddysee is still a satisfying experience.

You do need to grit your teeth through a number of unforgiving sections and checkpoints that can lose you a good couple of minutes of intricate setup over and over again, but when it all clicks it feels great, and the amazing world-building and aesthetic hold up to this day.

77434816.review:
Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is a classic platformer and a challenging game. The objective of this game is simply to pass many obstacles and reach the destination. There are many kinds of obstacles and you have to use your brain to overcome it.

Timing and precision is very important in this game. For instance, when the enemy see you, you have to immediately hide, run toward another zone, or climb the higher platform. One second late and the enemy will shoot you to death. After that, you have to start over from the latest checkpoint.

Gameplay-wise, this game is not bad, especially for a classic game. The main problem of this game is its loading time. The loading time took forever and very clunky.  As the result, dying in this game becomes very punishing, not because you have to repeat, but because the wait time until revival took so long. 

Another problem of this game is its control that is not smooth. It takes time to decelerate so if you're one second late to stop your running, you might crash into a shocker or a grinder then die. Of course you can always start over, but one slow motion revival process awaits you before that.

If the revival process is instant, i would have give positive review. Unfortunately, that's not the case.

77427251.review: This game is a test. What really made me like this game is how rewarding it is to just progress. It feels good to accomplish the near infinite amount of puzzles, where you hop, roll, and long jump your way to the goal. I even found some unintended solutions to a few puzzles and that was fun to find. This game is enjoyable and frustrating. Definitely worth playing. I swear, I'll save the Mudokons the next time I play, I didn't enjoy killing them that much.

For the 2020 me, this was a really nostalgic moment, remembering 1997 and replaying one of the first games I remember to play on my PC. I get the feeling that the young 10 year old me was getting creeped playing this, don't ask me why since it is only a feeling, I honestly I cannot remember it properly.
I get this feeling so many times while replaying a games. Sometimes I remember a smell, a moment or event that I lived during the period that I played that game, it is pretty odd I know, but what can I do? I guess that is my subconsciente working… 

Anyway, back to the game, Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is an iconic classic of the video game history. It is a 2D platformer. The game is visually low res, and you do not get any option to change it. But interesting enough, despite what the game state about the operating system, it worked pretty OK on Windows 10, something that is not very usual on such old games. 
Mechanically I played it better on keyboard than on my controller, I read some other people mentioning that on the reviews, so this is clearly not a case of my controller only. 

But while replaying this old "pearls", I always expect unforeseen circumstances or incompatibilities so for me that was not a surprise. Overall, and that is what is most important, I enjoyed replaying it, and for me, owning a game like this, is like own a piece of history. I honestly advise to grab it when you can...

70741626.review:
[h1]'Ello. Follow me.[/h1]
[i]Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee[/i] is an elusive game. It is a kid's platformer ostensibly, but then you look at the grim corporatism and the relentless destruction of the environment and this game feels really rather timeless. It is a marvelously difficult yet rewarding platformer, showcasing the explorations of several different worlds. The soundtrack is great and ambient, and the ability to speak to other Mudokons is quite cool too. Your objective is to save as many of your hapless friends as possible, but most of the time that is easier said than done. 

Considering how cheap this game is (and that at one point it was given out free in a giveaway) this game from my childhood is still definitely worth a play today, if you want to play a difficult old platformer, or see the same problems from this 1997 video game still alive and unfortunately well in our own world today. It's also good preparation for the new Oddworld game that's coming to the PlayStation 5, Oddworld: Soulstorm. Can't wait for that!

69537395.review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 14.1h (based on steam, game completed, bad ending)

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee® is a puzzle game with a bit of stealth element where you have to dodge obstacles and avoid enemies to save your fellow aliens from being killed.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 2 endings
- Secret areas
- Freedom to save or kill the aliens
- Puzzles are not too easy and not too hard either 

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Cutscenes don't run smoothly
- Terrible controls
- Tile-based and slow movement
- Weird saving mechanics

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]Actually, I wanted to not recommend this game because of the cons, but the game is pretty cheap on sale and I enjoyed it a lot from the mid-game. If you think the controls aren't to your liking, you can try to buy the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/314660/Oddworld_New_n_Tasty/]remake[/url] instead.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
It might be obvious for a game that was released in 1997, but the graphic looks pixelated for a 3D game, possibly because of its low resolution. It might take some time to get used to it and I don't see any problem after that.

The main menu is simple and unique; you can see the main character popping out from the middle and respond to whatever option that you choose. I especially like it when he said "Hello" after the menu loaded.

The environment, on the other hand, looks spooky and mysterious. It works well with the fact that the main character is an alien and you're running away from the place you were in.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is being told by Abe, the character that you control, by voice. The voice is crystal clear although my poor listening skills can't seem to comprehend some of the words that he said. It might also because of the horrible cutscenes though.

By all means, the cutscenes aren't that bad. I watched some videos and I find it to be okay. However, the cutscenes don't run smoothly in my screen somehow; they are missing a lot of frames that each frame looks way different from the last and I had to imagine the missing frames in my head, not to mention that the transition between frames are triggered by some static-like thing that you can see in old TVs. All in all, it wasn't a pleasant experience to watch.

[h1]The game[/h1]
[b]Exploration[/b]
The game has 7 main areas that you can explore in order. You have to go past the enemies and dodge any obstacles to make sure you don't die. Since you're pretty weak in the first part of the game, stealth becomes the main part of the game. The obstacles will also become harder as you progress that you may need to try several times, often by trial and error, just to get through it.

There are also some checkpoints after you solve several areas. These are indicated by a green square-like thing above your head. 

I enjoyed the game more after the mid-game because it's starting to divide the area into smaller parts. There will be a map placed in the "hub" area that will show the map layout in a Metroidvania style and you can enter each smaller area in any order that you want. These smaller areas are usually connected; you have to formulate your strategy based on all of the available rooms to reach the goal.

[b]Puzzles[/b]
One thing that I know from a good puzzle design is to make a puzzle that isn't too easy and not too hard that the player will give up after one try. This game does this perfectly. There are a lot of diverse actions that you can take to reach the goal and you can always try the other "routes" if one doesn't work.

[b]Ability[/b]
Although you can control a particular enemy when you meet the right condition from the early game, it won't be introduced until you reach the third area. It will make it harder to 100% the game on your first try if you don't know about this ability because of this.

Another ability will also be introduced later in the game. You also can pick up bombs and meats and throw them to the enemies to kill or lure them.

[b]Controls[/b]
I didn't enjoy the game at first because of the controls. Although the game is in 3D, strangely, it uses a tile-based system like what an RPG Maker game does, except that you can't tell whether the very edge of a platform is walkable or not. I can't count how many times I fell to my death because I thought I can stand on the edge platform.

The character also walks too slow that I tend to press the buttons too fast. There was a time where I need to dash, jump, and grab a platform where I suddenly decide to cancel all that and go to the other way instead of jumping. The thing is, the game remembers most of the control that you pressed - you won't move right if you press right when you're still on "dashing to the left" animation; you'll have to wait until you finish jumping and grabbing a platform to do that.

There is also a control that the game explains wrong in the tutorial. The tutorial said that you need to press shift and alt to chant although you need to press 0 to do that.

The game also requires you to do a technique that wasn't taught in the tutorial; you can change from dashing to rolling quickly by pressing x while dashing. There is no way to know that the technique exists if you don't know it beforehand and it's mandatory to do that in some part of the game. I even thought that the game was impossible to beat at some point because I didn't know that combination.

[b]Mudokons[/b]
There are 99 mudokons, your alien race, in the game. You can choose to either kill them or save them. Saving them all will net you a bonus after you finish the game and you need to save at least 50 to get a good ending. I only saved ~40 of them and I got a bad ending instead.

[b]Secret areas[/b]
There are a lot of secret areas in the game. These secret areas usually lead to more enemies and mudokons that you can save. They are hard to find though and I only encountered a few of them throughout the game.

[b]Saving[/b]
You can only save on certain checkpoints and you can only do it once per "save point". Sure, you can save multiple times, but it will only record the first time you reached that area. I even thought that the game autosaved because of that and had to redo some areas because I didn't save at some point.

[b]Difficulty[/b]
Actually, the game isn't that difficult. However, the controls and save mechanics increase the difficulty. If you're up for more challenges, you also can increase the difficulty by trying to save all mudokons.

[b]Replayability[/b]
You actually can 100% the game in your first playthrough. However, you might have to learn some controls that are taught later in the game somewhere else to do that.

You can replay the game to try to save all mudokons in the game and obtain a bonus ending. If you got a bad ending in your first playthrough like me, the game will automatically spawn you to the last area of the game so you can try to aim for a good ending. I'm not in the mood to get that though so I finished playing after that.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's a great puzzle game with a bit of stealth element. However, the controls are terrible and the save mechanic is making the game harder. However, if you don't mind with it, you'll have a lot of fun with this game.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/23741321]Follow our curator page[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b], if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

69020146.review:
As the title suggests, it is a very odd world indeed. Game itself is both puzzle and action platformer. First you solve how to overcome the obstacle you facing (puzzle part) which is moderately difficult, but executing it is much harder. While moving, each step you  take can be critical to your success, and one little extra or less step might ruin it, that also includes jumping and crouching. It takes quite a lot of precision to execute your actions. 

That being said, something really annoyed me with the game. At a certain part of the game, you come across a broken well, and in order to magically repair it, you have to kill three enemies, which makes absolutely no sense even in context of extremely odd nature of the game and overall gameplay. I don't mind looking at walkthroughs, and when reading them, I have always felt like - I could solve this if I wanted to. But this one didn't make sense at all. Along with all the different pathways and stuff I thought the game is perhaps best for those who like old school hardcore mystery puzzle games that doesn't hold your hand at all. It isn't my thing.

67686316.review:
[h1]===GAMEPLAY===[/h1]
The game is a classic 2D platformer with a static screen.
Despite all the video-solutions on youtube the game is still challenging as the puzzles are not too hard and play on the user's reflexes (for example pressing a button in a specific and short moment).

[h1]===BUGS/MISSED OPPORTUNITIES===[/h1]
The only oppressing bugs come from the conversion from PS1 to Computer format (for example the game may crash sometimes or launch in a low resolution). Except that the game has never shown any missed opportunity or bug to me.

[h1]===GRAPHICS===[/h1]
The graphics is certainly old, however it's still acceptable and enjoyable in its clarity (you don't really stop asking yourself what you're looking at).

[h1]===REPLAYABILITY===[/h1]
The game is not replayable since everything is static (the enemies, platforms and traps will always spawn in the same place no matter how many times you play the game).

[h1]===FINAL VERDICT===[/h1]
The game is so challenging you will likely spend over two hours trying to save the same slaves over and over without realizing, definitely worth buying for 3 € regardless of whether you used to play it or not.

[i](My apologies for any mistakes, I'm not a native English speaker.)[/i]

65294705.review:
An obvious masterpiece that took me 20 years from the first "Hello" to watching the final titles roll. I had a part of the first level on a demo disk that came with my PS1 back in 1998, and even though the game did catch my attention with its setting, visual style and, above everything, its giggling and farting protagonist, I found the gameplay a bit too cumbersome and didn't get the full version (and I was too busy playing NFS3, Silent Hill and Resident Evil anyway).
A decade later I remembered it, started playing it on the PC and realized that what I had once found a bit too cumbersome of a gameplay was exactly what made the game so unique, immersive and captivating. However much I enjoyed it, I obviously lacked the dexterity required to cope with its notorious checkpoint system, so little by little my patience was wearing thin, and the Paramonian Temple became the final straw.
Yet another decade later, I started it all over again, this time on a PS1 emulator and with two buttons on the gamepad dedicated to saving and loading states. Finally, I was able to enjoy it thoroughly. Looking back, I would never have been able to complete the game any other way — some segments, like the final chase in the Scrabanian Temple, would've been just way too much for me; rescuing all the Mudokons would've been just as impossible. Also, the controls seem more accurate and responsive in the PS1 version. So, take my advice: if you're clumsy like me and the checkpoint system is starting to get on your nerves, just forget it and go the emulator way — being able to enjoy a great game at your own pace is worth much more than the higher resolution of the PC version.

63881636.review:
Obra maestra arruinada por una basura de port que no está a la altura.

Como juego es excelente y un clásico de la vieja Playstation, pero los controles son lo peor que he visto en la vida. Se solapa el Gamespeak con los movimientos, sufriendo una ligera demora que no casa con un título plataformas o la experiencia real en consola. Además este problema lleva a situaciones como querer correr y saltar para que Abe acabe lanzando un silbido (lo cual te convierte en carroña o comida para Slogs, Paramitas o Scrabs). He tratado de modificarlos, pero al arrancar el juego vuelven a la distribución por defecto. Una pena que se decanten por vender algo en un estado tan lamentable que siquiera trae Steam Overlay.

Si te mueres por echarle el diente, recomiendo un emulador o desempolvar la vieja PSX para los que aun conservamos material de tanto calibre. Si tu única opción es el PC, entonces sugiero que utilices este motor que han diseñado para pulir los distintos ports de los dos juegos de Oddworld originales:

https://aliveteam.github.io/index.html

Solo hay que añadir dos archivos a la carpeta local del juego y arrancar desde el ejecutable. Debido a que se utiliza un .exe distinto al de Steam, no contará el tiempo y no habrá acceso a Steam Overlay/toma de capturas de marras (aunque esto último ya es un problema original del port). Para solucionarlo existe esta simple herramienta que fue diseñada para Fallout 2 pero puede aplicarse a cualquier juego:

https://nma-fallout.com/threads/steamdetour-run-fallout-mods-from-steam.220425/

Con ambas herramientas listas, solo hay que añadir los parámetros de lanzamiento y Abe's Oddysee funcionará en tu PC moderno sin problemas. Además podrás tomar capturas de pantallas para que tus amigos vean que eres perro viejo.

61947543.review:
I completely understand why this game is a classic. The visuals are intriguing and even really good for the time, the puzzles are well built and require a lot of thought, the soundtrack is great, and the game has a lot of replay value in rescuing all 99 Mudokons and finding where they are at. And though many people love this game it is definitely not for me and I see a lot of problems with it in fact. First of all, neither platformers nor puzzle games are really my thing. I love strategy games and some puzzle games, and there are plenty of other games done in a 2D style I enjoy, but this game has some really annoying flaws (mostly due to it's age). 

The biggest issue I have is the controls. I noticed this in the main menu, first off the controls are just a little wacky, but when I tried to rebind the crouch key to make it more comfortable for me it would not let me. No big deal though I would make it work. When I got into game though I ran into a far bigger issue the controls felt both unresponsive at times and slick at others. This causes several problems, first being that this game causes you to think on your toes a lot and when things respond poorly you die... a lot... The next issue is that even when you can respond properly at times (specifically with the run) you will slide slightly, which got me killed more that a couple times. Now this alone does not ruin a game, but the bigger problem is that this leads to A LOT of deaths and this game is not kind to those who die. Now I don't mind punishment I am a huge fan of the Dark Souls series and I am used to taking a beating especially when I have made a mistake, but this game has a horrible respawn mechanic. It does give you unlimited lives, but whenever you respawn it tends to put you fairly far back and will not remember and people you have saved making this game extremely repetitive at times. The game is even more repetitive because most of the puzzles and platforming have a singular correct way to solve them, which makes the game far too linear for me to enjoy. Also this is common among old games and is not a huge deal, but I had to modify the game to make it work as well, which is annoying, but was an easy fix. I really don't enjoy Abe's voice either.

Honestly I would like to give this a mixed review. It is fairly dated, controls really poorly at times,  is overly repetitive, and was just not my kind of game. That being said if it interests you it is definitely worth a try, but it is not a game I plan on playing again.

[b]NOTE:[/b] Use DXWnd to play game in windowed mode. Don't bother with ddraw hacks. Make sure AbeWin.exe does not have reduced color mode checked in compatibility tab (otherwise colors will be wrong)

[u][h1]The Bottom Line:[/h1][/u]
This game is pretty unique. Though it uses game mechanics that had been there for a while - such as the “trial and error - jump'n'puzzle” game, however, it adds a unique world with fascinating creatures and new gameplay elements like communication. The puzzles take some time to solve - and the game requires you to have good timing skills to perform the actions. Abe's Oddysee can get frustrating as you need to try some running and jumping parts over and over again to get to the goal. But it is also quite fun and satisfying once you solve puzzles. 
In overall a very good game and the prerendered 2D graphics look good even today. The ambient soundtrack is a plus to the atmosphere of Oddworld.

60999395.review:
I don't know what to say, really. I never played any Oddworld game before despite all evidence pointing I was missing out on something. There are so many games! and they are all praised! then I saw a sale of the whole collection and bought all of them. Without knowing how I would like any of them. You know, like an idiot would.

So I played for less than 2 hours and my opinion is likely not going to change: it's someone's magnum opus, for sure. The amount of detail and love is obvious at every corner. Probably the most deep and complex grid platformer (cinematic platformer) out there. You need to rescue others, and you do so by giving commands to follow and wait, you need to avoid enemies by creeping or setting up traps. There are grenades you can throw. You can possess enemies and have them kill each other or pull switches for you. There really is a lot going on here. 

Where the game falls flat is repetition. In the 90s we didn't have as many games to choose from as now, so games could afford to be... how can I put this? disrespectful with your time? Like [i]"aww are you losing your patience? Maybe you want to play something else instead? what's that? you get 3 games to play a year? oh jeez whiz what a shame! Better respawn now then"[/i] At one point I spent 20 minutes playing the same section until I did all I wanted to do there. Rescued all dudes. Only to find out there was no checkpoint afterwards and I lost that progress, and the save function doesn't work like you would think it does. The puzzle part was fun to solve, the rest was just trial and error. A ludicrous amount of trial and error mixed with the worst possible gameplay element: puzzles. Puzzle and trial and error are not a harmonious match.

I can't say this is a bad game. But I don't want to put more time into it either so, for practical purposes, it's the same as a bad game. Unless you played this back in the day and want to relive your memories, I recommend passing on Oddworld. 

A lot of people also complaint about bugs and crashes. I got a few of those but never during gameplay, usually during menus.

56742618.review:
The Oddworld series is a rare example of a creative team finding the exact perfect tonal point for a game satirising conspicuous consumerism by blending just the right amounts of gritty grimdark corporate industrialism with quirky, wacky, off-the-walls humour in such a way that it perfectly creates this horrific mercantile dystopian setting that still remains fun and engaging to explore the world and lore of.

This aforementioned sci-fi alien world is the vehicle for the titular Abe to engage in a quest to emancipate his downtrodden slave-caste species from their oppressors from their brutal reality. 

Gameplay itself sees the player control Abe as he navigates through a number of platform-puzzle screens each filled with an array of vicious trigger-happy enemies, deadly mechanical traps, and environmental hazards designed to bring about a quick end to yourself and the number of friendly NPCs Abe will have in-toe at any given time. 

The aim of gameplay is to safely lead as many of these NPCs through the levels in your wake after clearing the way of danger. While Abe may be totally lacking in combat ability or any substantial physical prowess whatsoever, he does possess a great capacity to instruct his freed brethren to work together cohesively, with an extensive array of commands able to be issued to friendly characters at any time during gameplay.

Abe’s Oddysee pulls no punches in delivering a gameplay experience that while not obtuse, is still mercilessly challenging - especially if one aims to achieve the ‘good’ ending where a majority of Abe’s followers live to see freedom, or heaven forbid, a perfect ending with no casualties whatsoever. Nevertheless, such difficulty only means you will be able to drink in all of Oddworld’s delicious charm and fantastically detailed art design and credible megacorp-run world design.

If you’re looking for a great classic platformer that runs on the world slow and contemplative side of things, this is it. If you’re seeking a bit of late-Nineties nostalgia ported over to Steam with the usual bells and whistles of Trading Cards, Badges, and a great deal of community support, you’ve found it. Or if you just want to mess around in a charming and unique little reactive sci-fi world that has room for simultaneous corporate satire, religious allegory, and a slave-race of bipedal lizard-men that can make fart jokes and chuckle to themselves throughout their wretched existence, this is that oddly specific thing you want.

Recommended.

50959733.review:
"Hello."

An ancient Adventure game, which aged terribly... which is understandable. What is not understandable is it doesn't have Steam overlay, which limits the access of Steam's social and browsing features, and disables taking screenshots. Not that there is anything good-looking to be captured, considering how bad this game looks, but despite its ancient graphics I have noticed how realistic the movement of the main character alien is. In the past developers didn't have 3D graphics, nor nearly as good program development tools and hardware as some developers have them nowadays, but they found ways to mimic realism by recording motion of the real actors. Unfortunately, not many do that nowadays, as most developers settle with making good-looking graphics, but that does not necessarily increase the immersion, if the physics are not mimicking reality.

Oddworld - Abe's Oddysee is dated, 2D Adventure game, with weird, outlandish art style, where the character moves in two directions, must jump over obstacles and traps, climb the obstacles, sneak, hide and avoid the detection of the enemies, while moving through the factory, which used to be the working place of the main character, before he found out what was going on with his management.

The game is too old for anyone to care, let alone to recommend it to someone, but people who played it back in the days know all they need to know about it, as they go on their nostalgia trip. Some things should stay in the past. It sends crash message every time I exit the game. Not recommended.

"Goodbye."

50748254.review:
This is the very first game in the "Oddworld" series developed by Oddworld Inhabitants. In this game you play as a Mudokon (alien creature ) named Abe who thinks he has the perfect job at Rupterfarms which is a meat processing plant that makes well... food.  He's views of he's employer and company change one night as he was waxing the floor with a floor cleaning machine he eventually stumbles across a meeting that was probably not meant for he's eyes to see. You see profits had been drying up for Rupterfarms and they weren't bringing in as much wildlife to turn into food as they were once able to do.  Abe discovers during the same meeting that he's company of employment plans to turn their factory slaves into food. Abe panics and makes a run for it and attempts to save as many Mudokons as he can along the way. 

It's the players choice whether he / she wants to save Mudokons or not. Failure to save a majority of them will result in of course a bad ending, saving most / all of them will result in a good ending. 

This game has ran perfectly fine on my modern day gaming computer. The only problem I want to note is all the FMV's (Full Motion Videos) stutter very badly but I've seen the games FMV's a million times during my life so it doesn't really bother me but may annoy those who are getting into the game and want to understand the story further.

50134052.review:
I was aware of Abe as a character from late 90s video gaming but I’d never actually played the game so when this was being given away free I thought I’d give it a go and I did not like it. It starts off well. I like the characters and world. It looks good, if a little dated. It started of with a nice slow paced puzzle platformer where you can take your time to think about how to progress and feel satisfied when you succeed.

As I got a little further it started to annoy me. The game gives you tutorial messages in the background but doesn’t tell you everything you need when you need it. For example it tells you about rescuing other Mudokons after you have already missed a bunch of them. I then got stuck at a particular section so I saved and took a break only to find it did not load at the checkpoint where I was when I saved it. I ended up having to replay an extra chunk of the game. Not only that but it did not save my custom key bindings and had even left one of the actions unbound.

A bit further into the game I got stuck again and turned to a walkthrough where I found I had missed numerous hidden sections of the game which looked devilishly hard. The walkthrough also revealed I was not not missing anything with the bit I was stuck on it was just my timing was off. I spent a good chunk of time trying and failing to get this section right and I gave up at this point as I was no longer having any fun. Contributing to this was also the thought that even if I got past that section there was no guarantee that if I saved it would not restart me before this horrible section again.

I know this review is going to get down voted into oblivion because these masochistically difficult games are unfathomably popular and also this game is sufficiently old that nostalgic people will see this as a personal attack on their childhood. But if some people who like relaxing casual puzzle games see this review and know not to waste their time here then my work is done.
