The rest comes together beatifully, even if it might not stand out as much for me.
Similar feeling was evoked in Necrum part of Abe's Exoddus for me, I love listening to both tracks of these locations, even though it's just very minimal ambient.

The gameplay aspect is pretty good, if not for controls that sometimes feel wonky, sometimes sporadic checkpoints (mostly missing in any hidden areas), and weird level design decisions at points that cause a lot of pointless down time (countless slogs coming out of the vaults that get less exciting each time you have to shoot through all of them again upon death) - the platforming, throwing, shooting and sneaking feels very satisfying when it's done consistently. The animation and sound also compliment those gameplay elements, you can easily react on distinctive sound cues, and grounded animations with believable movement make handling the character more intuitive.

The sidescrolling of levels also is well done, while the parts are interconnected, what can interact between them is limited. The limits are pretty easy to figure out (most chasing enemies, thrown items, but not bullets and detectable sounds), and don't feel like an unfair playing field.

The dark humor in the game was enjoyable, though the slapstick elements weren't really in my taste (even back in elementary school).
There is also social commentary on corporatism and consumerism, which while heavy handed - works quite well with the dystopian setting it wanted to achieve.

I'm happy that they tried to remake the game with some improvements in New n Tasty, though certain elements that I praised here were altered for a bit worse - animations feel oddly sped up, there is bloom everywhere, which detracts from the original's gloomy and grounded visuals, and the sidescrolling is now altered to constant camera movement, rather than transitions.

I can recommend the original definitely, when it comes to the unique experience, it still offers the most, despite the technical flaws. One last point is that it crashes when you exit (not alt-tab) it on W7, which affects nothing really, but is something that will not be patched anytime soon.

48337684.review:
If you played Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee as a kid, then chances are that its a game that is so engraved in your mind that years in the future you still find yourself vividly remembering the weird foreign sounds made by the enemies, the alien oppresive industrial setting and beautiful dark pre-rendered backgrounds, the way Abe moves around and talks, or how relentlessly punishing and distressing it can be.
I never managed to beat the game as a kid. In fact, i dont think I ever even got around to getting out of the first area, Rupture Farms. But Oddworld: Abe's Odysee was always one of those games I always held in high esteem and put alongside my favourites of all time. I think some of you have that sort of game as well, a game you never managed to finish but you still consider a favourite. 
But the memories always stuck with me, it left a mark that Im certain influenced my taste in videogames to come. So after all these years, I decided to finally get some closure and fullfill this love by actually finishing the game.
Starting the game, its easy to see why this game manages to leave such an impression on the people who play it. After all these years, it still retains some of the best worldbuilding, art design, background art and characterization I have ever seen in a videogame. In a few short minutes, everything you need to know bout this world, story and characters is introduced and soon enough you are thrown into the thick of it without handholding.
As a slave fugitive, your quest is to escape the dystopian farm that has enslaved you before they turn you into one of their own products for consumption. You control an unlikely hero, Abe, who doesnt possess any offensive actions whatsoever, besides the ability to possess certain enemies.
This being a cinematic platformer (in the vein of games like Another World and Flashback), most of the challenge of the game is in assessing the situations that present themselves on each screen and maneuvering Abe's realistic animations in an attempt to reach the next alive. It's not so much a game about knowing how to jump on platforms, but about solving puzzles by jumping on platforms. There are definitely some cases of trial and error, but for the trained eye and observant player, there are always signs on the screen of how things will play out and if you are smart enough to catch them you can always get a small chance to escape death.
 And make no mistake, you will die. Alot. One of the greatest aspects of the game is in how it makes you feel each death. The goofy Abe face that greets you on the title screen might trick you into thinking this a kiddy game, but the violence is as realistic as it gets. The game is riddled with beasts that will hunt you down, patrolling guards that will pulverize you with rifles, mines that will blow you up on contact, bombs that will explode if you pass by the security laser, etc. Every single death in this game drives the thematic oppression home, and it really turns the game into a very unique and uncomfortable experience.
Which makes the small victories all that more rewarding. Figuring out a solution to a challenging section and managing to surpass it while a ravaging beast chases you down and you escape in the nick of time is frankly an experience that not many games are able to achieve, not even the ones who have to rely on scripted events. And Abe's Odysee is filled with these experiences.
Besides the obvious dystopian subject matter, Abe's Odyssee also deals with themes of nature preservation and ecosystem  balance. Playing this now, I got the chance to leave Rupture Farms and explore the alien wildlife of Oddworld, and here the game really manages to contrast the beauty of nature versus the depravity of the factory, all without much exposition or beating you over the head. Even outside the factory, the world is still dangerous and vicious, but the presentation of the backgrounds and ambient soundtrack bring out this sense of peace and equilibrium that is sorely missing in Rupture Farms, the place you know you will have to go back to again to save your fellow Mundokon friends.
I can safely say that Oddworld: Abe's Odysee definitely stands the test of time. Its a beautiful game that offers a fair and memorable challenge with the perfect duration. I am now reassured of my adoration for this game and it gets my Certified Classic seal of approval. Now onto the sequel!

Its still easy to appreciate the factors that made this game so popular back when released, quirky humour, beautifully drawn backdrops, challenging but not rediculously so and (when on sale) all that for just a £1. I am aware that 'Oddworld: New 'n' Tasty' is an updated version of this game and so probably deals with any slight criticisms I have about this version of the game but I haven't got round to playing that yet (nostalgia won out).

If you're in to platform games or just need a break from more immersive kinds of game, for the cost of less than a cup of coffee (admittedly, I do think highstreet coffee is overpriced), how can you go wrong?

47618426.review:
Clunky puzzler that punishes 

Warning: the game does not properly run in full screen mode and does require a mod. Simply pasting the 2 files into the game's folder gets it to work.

Overview
Abe is a slave who finds out that he, and the others are to be processed into food. The player is to rescue Abe and as many slaves along the way.

Gameplay
The controls are simple. Players can walk, run, stealth, and jump as well as interact with slaves using voice prompts. Almost all the interactions are very clunky, which would be okay, if the game did not require a good amount of precision particularly in getting other slaves to move where you want so you can save them. Sometimes you have to ask them to follow you 3 times in a row so they line up close enough to make it through an obstacle then repeat this process 2-3 times.  And then rescue another slave and repeat the process. unless they die and you have to start over again, and I mean the entire area. I spent an hour replaying one region over and over again, already knowing how to solve it, but needing to go through all the motions to get the the point that was tricky. Once i cleared that I finally progressed to a new area and promptly died. So it resets all 6-7 areas i've cleared a dozen times. That gets frustrating pretty quickly. Also 0 is used as the chant command (you can see it in the dialogue menu in the options) though the ingame prompts alt+shift don't work.

The game definitely doesn't hold your hand as there are 2 very important aspects that are given no mention. I only cleared 2 sectors before I simply lost any sense of enjoyment, so maybe the game eventually tells you about them, but I can only imagine the frustration of giving up on saving a slave only to find out later you could have easily saved them. And thus have to clear all those past regions again. In fact, one of them makes several areas incredibly easy. What a weird design option to create puzzles requiring repetition and tight timings to complete but then just have a way to negate large parts of them.

Presentation
The game is from 1997, so it's dated, but interesting. The factory and character designs are creepy, perhaps more so with the older graphics. There are also some subtle visual cues to provide information and I didn't have any issues with the sound outside of one area that was just a mash of processing noises that were much louder then the other audio throughout the parts i played.

Overall
Short review because i didn't progress far into the game before simply finding it annoying. This has all the old school challenges and nostalgia for some, but the repeating 3-4-5 puzzles until you learn how to clear puzzle 6 is to much of a grind in which much of the challenge seemed to be the game not telling you things or the controls being cumbersome

I think I got it! The game is using an internal scaler. With the start up command "-interline" the game disables this scaler producing an interlaced image. This can then be corrected with the Dxwnd deinterlace filter.

So to set up the game in Dxwnd try the following:

In the Main tab configure the Path and Launch fields:
Path: C:\Abe's Oddysee\AbeWin.exe
Launch: C:\Abe's Oddysee\AbeWin.exe -interline

In the DirectX tab configure the filter:
Filter->deinterlace.[/quote]

https://store.steampowered.com/app/15700/Oddworld_Abes_Oddysee/
Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee was not only very weird, brutally hard but also a great puzzle game released in 1997. 
Unfortunately the game itself aged very, very poorly. 
Controls are clunky, no support for modern resolutions, very punishable checkpoints combined with often trial and error gamplay is a really frustrating experience.
This is why I cannot recommend it anymore unless you are some kind of hardcore Abe's  fanboy or something. The game is just no longer worth of playing in this day and age.
Thats why Oddworld: New 'n' Tasty exist.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/314660/Oddworld_New_n_Tasty/
Oddworld: New 'n' Tasty is built from scratch, enhanced and improved version of Abe's Oddysee.
Every single thing, good and bad, about Abe's Oddysee got improved: protagonist voice, visuals, sound quality, music, level design, gameplay, controls, puzzles, difficulty settings, controlling mudokon's...

Additionally the game now have way more and fair checkpoint system that won't punish you with repeating the last 40 minutes of your game everytime.

Also wanna try to get a good ending after finishing the game? No problem, just select chapters that you need to finish in 100% and then replay the last level. No need to restart entire game anymore.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/323341/Oddworld_New_n_Tasty__Alfs_Escape_DLC/
New 'n' Tasty also got a very good 2 hour long DLC called "Alf's Escape".
Its build of the most difficult and unique puzzles in the whole game. Definitely worth of its price.

Truly this is how video game remakes should be made.

43964702.review:
Abe's Oddysee was the first platformer I ever played as a kid, and it absolutely astonished me back then with how fun - and difficult - the levels were.  Coming back to the game as an adult, it's clear that Oddysee was way ahead of it's time, not only in the gameplay department, but also graphically as well.  The game barely looks dated by today's standards - it is pixelated, but the hand-painted backgrounds and sprites and the consistent art style help alleviate that a lot.

As it's name suggests, Abe's Oddysee definitely stands out from your typical 2D platformer.  For one, Abe is a very slow, clumsy guy, and so his jumping and mobility is very limited compared to the likes of Mario or Sonic.  For this reason, most situations require a combination of lite platforming and solving a puzzle.  Second, Abe is defenseless (except for a very limited supply of grenades), and so must use stealth, traps, evasion, or possession to get past enemies.  Possession is an amazing mechanic that reminds me of a much newer platformer (Mario Odyssey; weird coincidence with the names there), and the game does an excellent job of limiting your use of possession and forming puzzles around it.  For some of the creatures you encounter, you also need to understand how they interact with you, each other, and the environment, which is an awesome bit of emergent gameplay that makes them feel like real animals instead of programmed enemies.  I'm pretty sure most of these ideas were completely new and unheard of in 1997.

Bottom line, Abe's Oddysee is one of the best and most innovative platformers from the 90s, and it still holds up beautifully today.  If you like platformers that are less about precise jumping and more about exploration and puzzle solving, you will find much to love in Oddysee and it's spin-off, Abe's Exoddus.

Seguramente la editora ha apostado por dejar la buena resolución en el "Oddworld: New 'n' Tasty" y dejar a este que se lo coman los Slig.

El juego es muy dificil y frustrante con controles y mecanicas complicadas. La mayoria de gente que lo tiene seguramente es porque le salió gratis o por filantropía de la época de los 32 bits. A no ser que te salga tirado de precio o te pueda la nostalgia no te va a parecer buena compra teniendo la oferta de juegos que hay hoy día.

Nota: [b]6/10[/b]

42760830.review:
Abbes Oddissey/Exodus  fué uno de esos juegos paridos en aquel trienio de años en el que servidor , humildemente , cree que los videojuegos tocaron techo en cuanto a desarrollo , mecánicas y formas de expresar una historia.  
 
Zelda Ocarina of time, Metal gear Solid, Reisident Evil 2 , Final Fantasy VII , Starcraft , Goldeneye , Quake 2 , Diablo 2 , Perfect Dark, Unreal Tournament , Shadowman y un ENORME tanto por ciento de títulos que olvido... 1997,1998 y 1999 asusta por la cantidad titanes que se lanzaron. Juegos que definieron y casi podría decirse que crearon géneros , pautas que aun a día de hoy se respetan a rajatabla .  
 
Abbes Oddissey y su secuela , Abes Exodous fueron 2 de estos juegos. Tapados por sus hermanos mayores, la propuesta de ambos juegos proponía una historia más íntima, más sesuda , cerebral y emocional que cualquiera de los juegos lanzados en aquellos años.  
 
Una historia que toca palos adelantadísimos a su época, temas como la explotación laboral, la tiranía, el medio ambienta o el racismo. En ella se nos enseña la primera pieza de un apasionante universo que lamentablemente ha sido muy maltratado en posteriores secuelas, el mundo de Oddworld. Una dimensión donde una raza esclavista, los Glukons, utiliza como ganado al resto de especies que pueblan ese mundo ,una historia en la que Abe, un miembro de estas razas, los Mudokons, se rebela no solo para salvar su pueblo, sino incluso a todo el mundo del yugo opresor de estos depredadores empresariales .  
 
Para ello debíamos movernos con un control tremendamente exigente al mas puro estilo de los clásicos Prince of Persia por unos escenarios 2D a la antigua usanza, repletos de enemigos y trampas, escenarios sin scroll alguno, donde debíamos guiar hacia la libertad utilizando ordenes verbales a unos compatriotas esclavizados, que dicho de paso, no es que fuesen muy avispados, terminando en la mayoría de ocasiones transformados en poco menos que puré de mudokon.  

Nuestro personaje , Abe era alguien completamente indefenso y las únicas herramientas para defendernos consistían en nuestra capacidad de sigilo y la posibilidad de poseer mentalmente a enemigos y otros seres ( con catastróficos resultados). 

La historia, apasionante de principio a fin no se cortaba a la hora de mostrarnos las tremendas perrerias a las que los Glukons sometían al resto de seres vivimos del mundo de Oddworld: bocas cosidas, descargas eléctricas para ordeñar lágrimas, plantas procesadoras de carne, canibalismo. Una historia que nos hacía empatizar con nuestro verde protagonista, y terminar su historia de principio a fin.  
 
Lo mejor:  
-Un juego de 1997 que supone toda una leccion de diseño.  
-Historia apasionante.  
-Jugabilidad dura y exigente, pero asequible.  
-Música, escenas de video, diseño de escenarios...el mundo de Oddworld es una dimensión que desearemos visitar en más ocasiones.  
 
Lo peor:  
-Años a la venta en steam y años sin el doblaje en castellano. Has de hacerlo tu con un parche no oficial.  
-Problemas de compatibilidad con sistemas operativos actuales.  
-Compatibilidad con mando catastrófica.  
-El juego de 1997 sin más.

42017985.review:
It is sad that not many people remember this marvelous piece of work. Back in 90s, it was one of the finest and most successful cinematic platform games. When the industry switched all its energy to 3D genres, Abe (together with all brilliant works of its time) got lost in oblivion. The game has unique puzzle mechanics (even for today's standards), very interesting atmosphere and a political subtext, something very rare for a puzzle-based action game. 

Forget about the remake and just buy the original. Only downside is the unforgiving save-system.

While it's a decent game that offers you a unique setting (I'd say, a bit like a platformer combination of Fallout and The Neverhood) in a dystopian society of fantastic creatures, it falls short when it comes to actual gameplay. It's tediously repetetive. I spent 16 hours playing it, however most of the time I wasn't exploring, jumping or fighting, but instead repeating some quick time event I didn't master enough. There's A LOT of reloading sequences just because you weren't fast enough. Note the game offers only checkpoint-based saves, which, at some points, makes the gameplay even more tiresome.
And yet... I still was engrossed for all the sixteen hours. This has to mean something. The game is indeed rewarding when you actually make progress. It's just the steep learning curve that makes you think twice if that's actually what you paid for. Chances are you'll fall in love with it. There's just no guarantee.

Oddworld Abe's Oddysee is the very first game of the Oddworld series. A game in which you have to save your buddies from becoming the new fastfood product.  It's game with quite some hidden sadistic humor.

You play as Abe. An employee at Rupture Farms who makes the terrible discovery that his species is the new menu. Now he has to get the hell out of there! Help Abe escape and discover his true destiny and don't forget to save his friends on the way!

You have to sneak, run, hide, use your enviroment and take control of the enemy to ensure your escape. Abe's Oddysee is a 2D platform game.

It's an old game but the graphics are quite good for a game of its age. Unlike the remastered version, Oddworld New 'n Tasty, this game will play smoothly without any framerate issues on your PC.

Obviously, this is an old game, and it looks like it - but it doesn't really feel like it. Even now it feels fast-paced and the mechanics are nice. When the game gets running after the tutorial bit, it can give you a great deal of stress - when you wait for everything on the screen to line up perfectly for you to make your run, hoping everything will work perfectly. And then, when you get to the end of it, after trying your best not to leave anyone behind, and you figure you missed a few secrets here and there, so you start again just to find out there are so many secret areas to find, many of them basically staring you in the face and laughing at you.

The game is not easy, pretty long, and has amazing artwork and music to intensify the atmosphere - definitely worth it, even today.

39427330.review:
This game....

The graphics are what they are. They're not horribly ugly, but they're... readable.

The controls. I couldn't play the game. There's so many buttons. So many ***** buttons. I literally couldn't play this game on a controller (I have a Logitec and a Steam Controller) because I didn't have enough buttons to map to the buttons in the game. How many verbs does your character need?

I know I got the game for free, and it may be unfair that I'm posting a negative review, but I literally couldn't wrap my hands around all the verbs the game expects your character to do simultaneously and fluently, on a keyboard or on a controller (without enough buttons). You have to hold down sneak, then run, while moving and hitting different buttons to jump and activate levers and do goodness knows what else. It's clunky at best.

I don't have any nostalgia for this title, and part of me wonders if that is the sole reason this game has positive reviews.

39402284.review:
Okay, so I went back and decided to give this one another go for a bit, and I have to say that it shows its age. New and Tasty (something I have played but don't own on steam) definitely looks better, but that's expected. This is actually the less buggy between them (New and Tasty felt kind of messy to be honest, and I found bugs quicker in it).
The reason I'm coming back to review this old game is because it has pissed me off again and again and again. I literally tried to look up the history of the quicksave function, because without it, this game just sort of takes a steamy dump on your head and expects you to thank it for the pleasure of licking its smelly hole clean. It wouldn't be so bad if it remembered when you save Muds, so when you go through that bird portal for the fifth time, finally get the AI to do the thing you want it to do, and then end up messing up your timing because of the control delay (I figure this has more to do with the animation style of the game than anything else; it was a different time, after all), only to finally succeed on your sixth attempt, the game won't let you save your progress. Nope: If you die before a checkpoint, you will go back to the last checkpoint, no matter if you save manually (it saves to your last checkpoint) after finally managing to accomplish that difficult puzzle that takes perfect timing to accomplish. 
It just... doesn't feel very satisfying. I don't get a real sense of accomplishment out of this game, just an ease to my frustration before the next difficulty spike. Mostly it's the secrets that are a pain; many sections are just there to fool you, kill you, and force you to redo something because isn't that hard? Now you have to memorize this section, and look how hard it is! Gotta be perfect on that timing, bro.
I'm not recommending this game anymore. If you want to go back and experience Oddworld, maybe try Exoddus (the sequel) instead, because it has a quicksave function, which makes the game infinitely more enjoyable. Okay yeah, it's $3, so what? Would you pay someone to show you nice pictures while they repeatedly kick you in the groin? If your answer was a question about the kinds of pictures, you might like this game. 
If you enjoy difficult platformers, and don't mind being told you're an asshole when you didn't drag your face across the barbwire fence repeatedly for the "completionist" feeling of actually saving all the Muds, Oddworld is certainly one of the better old school games to get around here on a budget. But if you do, for godssake, just let those poor fools rot; they're not worth it.

37370100.review:
[h1] A Masterpiece of Puzzle Platforming [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2] 



Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is an absolute masterpiece that has stood the test of time. This game is a perfect blend of puzzle-solving and platforming, with a unique and captivating story that is sure to keep you engaged from start to finish.

The graphics may not be groundbreaking by today's standards, but they have a distinct charm that is hard to resist. The detailed and atmospheric environments breathe life into the game world, making it feel truly immersive. The level design is top-notch, offering a wide range of challenges that require both quick reflexes and brainpower to overcome.

But it's not just the gameplay that shines in Abe's Oddysee; the storytelling is exceptional as well. Through the use of captivating cutscenes and cleverly crafted dialogue, the game manages to convey a powerful message about corporate greed and the plight of workers. It's a thought-provoking experience that adds an extra layer of depth to the overall gameplay.

One of the game's standout features is the ability to possess and control enemies using Abe's unique powers. This mechanic adds a whole new dimension to the puzzles, as you can manipulate enemies to clear obstacles or even use them to eliminate their own kind. It's both satisfying and clever, showcasing the game's ingenuity.

Furthermore, the sound design in Abe's Oddysee is truly exceptional. The haunting, atmospheric soundtrack perfectly complements the dark and gritty visuals, enhancing the immersion and creating an eerie ambiance that resonates with the game's overall theme.

In terms of difficulty, Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee strikes a good balance. While some puzzles can be challenging, they are always fair and rewarding to solve. The sense of accomplishment when successfully navigating through a tricky level is incredibly satisfying, making every hurdle worth the effort.

In conclusion, Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is a remarkable game that should not be missed by any puzzle platforming enthusiast. Its unique blend of challenging gameplay, compelling storytelling, and memorable characters make it a true gem in the gaming world. Whether you're a longtime fan or new to the series, this game is a must-play that will leave a lasting impression.



[b] -Abe is Life itself. [/b]

36000886.review:
Abe's Oddysee continually pits you against insurmountable odds – or they would be insurmountable without infinite attempts – and still the greatest challenge of the game is Abe himself. I can't count the amount of times I was killed because Abe stopped one step too short to grab a ledge or needed to jump a little too soon after a screen transition. The game's controls suggest it was intended to be more of a point-and-click, where unrefined control isn't an issue. Then the level designer got a hold of it. Now its platforming requires so much precision (precision these loose controls just cannot support) that this game shows more of its age than it really should. 

The visuals aren't exactly to today's standards either. More than once I missed a pathway or an obstacle due to how difficult it can be to make out your surroundings. But the superb art direction more than makes up for it. Everything's so grotesquely interesting to look at that it's worth the eye strain.

Similarly, the challenges Abe faces are worth putting in the effort to solve. Their difficulty is made up of how many moving parts each puzzle has, so by the time you understand it, you feel like you've built your own Rube Goldberg machine. It can take several deaths to even figure out a part of what you should be doing and several more to actually do it. This can lead to a lot of repetition as you perform the same sequence you've already memorized over and over again to only catch a glimpse of the next challenge. 

For this reason, the most frustrating part of Abe's Oddysee – second only to the controls which certainly exacerbate the issue – is the placement of checkpoints. Sure, their spread out nature does ensure you've truly mastered the full sequence before you move on, but the road to that mastery can become so very dull, and the game drags because of it.

The lack of proper pacing surprisingly doesn't do much damage to the story being told here. On the contrary, the level of challenge only helps to emphasize how small Abe is and how enormous what he's up against is. It also provides a little narrative complexity when it comes to rescuing your fellow captive Mudokons. It's one thing to undertake an extra challenge in order to do what's right, it's another thing entirely to make that decision when you're already exhausted by the overwhelming trials behind and still in front of you. I found myself asking if these innocent Mudokons – no different than Abe/me – were worth saving, and that's not a question I ask myself often.

My experience with this game may have been mostly frustrating and unpleasant, but I'm still left wondering if I should try the 'New and Tasty' remake. I have no nostalgia for Oddworld as this was my first time through this game or any other in this series. But the world set up in Abe's Oddysee really gripped me. With tighter controls and a few more checkpoints, this might be a game I would come back to fairly regularly. But as it is, unless you're looking to relive an old experience, I can't recommend this version. It's not that it's a poor game at all, it's just that parts of it have aged so poorly that it's hard to see that sometimes.

35485989.review:
Jugué por primera vez este juego en 1999 o en el 2000 (no recuerdo con exactitud), era extremadamente complicado pero divertido al mismo tiempo. 

El objetivo principal es rescatar a tus "hermanos" Mudokons (la raza del protagonista) de una planta procesadora de carne antes de que todos ellos se conviertan en comida. No es fácil ya que el juego tiene puzzles y trampas que de a poco se vuelven más complicadas.

De chico apenas podía pasar unos niveles, pero luego siendo más cauteloso y atento pude encontrarle la mano. Tus acciones van a determinar el descenlace. 

Todo está en los números finales: si rescataste 50+ Mudokons (99 en total) vas a poder terminar el juego con el buen final.

 Si terminaste con menos de 50, ellos no van a ser capaces de salvarte cuando ya estés encima de una trituradora....

9/10 y espero pronto conseguir la versión remasterizada Oddworld: New 'n' Tasty

35432519.review: This is an old game.1997? And this is the original PS1 version. So with that, understand that the game graphics are eh, and  the game is clunky. But it definitely gives that platform, not forgiving if you mess up WHEW feel. Levels of endless puzzles, levers, dodging, sneaking, using your Elum/mount, using grenades/rocks, pipe shoots, jumping and CHANTING your way through. It's not easy. Chanting is the main thing in this game ( next to Game speak) because of it's many uses, and is like the Mudokon ''thing''. You play as Abe a once Mudokon slave at the Rapture Farms meat processing plant. He ''happened'' to find out that the boss Molluck the Glukkon of the Magog Cartel are going to use the Mudokon slaves as their next meat source!!!!! Oh, no, So he escapes out of the farms, the stockyard and out into the forest after having a vision from ''Big Head'' that his destiny is to rescue his people. So you have to platform crazy make your way through 2 temples, to gain the Shrykull ultimate CHANT to go back and defeat Molluck the Glukkon and free your peoples!  GREAT FICTION STORY LINE!!!! just a hard- hard game.  Other than the normal plat from ''stuff'' there is Game speak. Yes, you sometimes do have to talk to other Mudokon to gain abilities, have them follow or do things. It's an interesting gimmick. I know they revamped the game, but the original is still good and the story the same. Sometimes the game does crash or freeze though... No achievements though is a bummer, but there are hidden secret areas in the game to look for! and its a challenge. ENJOY or get New 'n' Tasty revamped version. Up to you.

35113903.review:
A very punishing stealth platformer game, you could probably determine whether you'll like the game based off the controls alone (and maybe the graphics but I'm not too nitpicky since the CG is pretty nice and the graphics themselves aren't so bad despite being low res) or perhaps if you are short on patience, failing a couple of times migth make you uninstall the game/ The game has a much bigger emphasis on stealth, emphasis and, for some rooms, making quick life or death situation than the beat-em-up or shoot-em-up elements found in other platformers.

Annoying things:
- Multiple rooms/Screens, this platform isn't a sidescroller so typically you are to navigate from one end of the room to the next. This game also happens to be one where enemies respawn if you leave a screen then come back to it later. Be warned.
- No windowed mode, in fact not a whole lot of game options besides sounds and controls. 
- No verticle jump or change in trajectory after you hit the jump key. The jump key which is by default bound to SPACE does a leap in the direction you are facing before initiating the jump. So at times, you want to scale a ledge and instinctively go for space but to jump up on a ledge you have to press the up arrow key. Really annoying at times because I prefer jumping up with SPACE, jumping left to SPACE + <- and right with SPACE + -> like it is with modern platformers. Also there is a slight delay in the jump and you will be confronted with a room with open pits and falling boulders very early on in the game and might need to retry it multiple times.
- Colorblind unfriendly, one mechanic in the game are mines you can disarm but only when they blink green. Sorry, as a colorblind person, I can't tell which is which although I was right to assume green was the brighter of the two colors.
- No lifebar, ONE HIT KILLS, you touch a dangerous item like a live mine or electric beam, you die, you touch an enemy's fired projectile, you die. Enemies will react fast and shoot you dead if you alarm them since your duck does not avoid their bullets. As a result the game is very punishing and leaves little room for error to clear the stages.

35102072.review:
This is a classic! Don't mind the time here, I actually played a lot on Playstation back in the day.

tl:dr This game is amazing! However it quite aged badly compared to the sequel and the remake.

You are Abe, a mudokon that is a "worker" (for not saying "slave") for the "lovely" place Rapture Farm. One day, while cleaning the main hallway, he overheards a meeting taked by the Glukkon, the owners of the slaughter house, in which, due to low income, they decide to make another slurpy snack made of... you! And your friend too! YUMMY!
You must help Abe to escape from Rapture Farm and free your friends from the Glukkon's tyranny and embark to an epic quest to discover his true destiny.
Or you can kill all your friends and still discover your destiny. You might not enjoy the ending though...
Usually I try to explain the gameplay in a somewhat professional way but, come on, it's Abe! One of the pillars of the Playstation era!
Back in the day it added one of the most innovative element mechanics for the "cinematic platform". This is the gamespeak, a system in which Abe can speak with his mudokon fellows to convince them to follow him to the closest escape point.
Now, I know this game is a classic and I recommend it because, come on, it's Abe! but I think that this game kind of aged badly compared to its sequels and the remake.
I am not talking about the graphic which is still amazing but I am talking about some of the most frustrating elements from the game, case in point the checkpoints and the high difficulty.
First of all, Abe's Oddysee it's hard and it is meant to be a "trial and error" kind of game. However the checkpoints are placed badly and you might redo a long session over and over again only for doing even the tiniest error, bringing more frustration rather that the "ah-AH!" moment tipical of the genre. That's why in later games they introduced the possibility to quicksave which even if some may say it lowered down the difficulty bar, it was undeniably more convenient than have to rerun a lot of screens only to do a jump better.
However it should be illegal to not reccomend this game because, come on, it's Abe! and even with the fact that it is very frustrating, it's still a classic that more people need to play.
I can't give a score this time since I know that my love of the game is mostly out of nostalgia.

[b][u]WARNING! READ AND FOLLOW THE FOLLOWING LINK BEFORE PLAYING AS GAME MAY CRASH YOUR PC AND WILL NEED TO HARD REBOOT YOUR PC![/u][/b]

[b][u]BACK TO REVIEW![/u][/b]

Without a doubt one of my favourite games of all time, which is [i]odd[/i] as I normally don't like platforming games too much. With that said, I played this beauty as a bab back on the good ol' Playstation One and, to this day, find it a difficult game, particularly if you want to get the "good ending" for this game. The game can be played with a keyboard, but I've always been more comfortable playing with a controller. The only negative thing I have to say about this game is that it doesn't have a quick-save system, leading to some frustration following deaths. Otherwise, here's what I love about Abe's Oddysee:

+ Great atmosphere, which has been tied together with an amazing, ambient soundtrack with beautiful background pieces that were hand-drawn.
+ Enjoyable, interesting characters and enemies, paired with some great sprite work and sprite animations.
+ Tiled-based movement system that controls perfectly.
+ Challenging platforming segments coupled with difficult puzzles in order to save your fellow Mudoken brethren.
+ Great looking cutcenes with equally amusing voice acting.
+ Command system ("game speak") is an interestingly quirky mechanic, as well as the possession system.
+ Odd

32088338.review:
I absolutely adore this game. An immersive and unique atmosphere is mixed with challenging yet rewarding gameplay, based around escaping from the homicidal Glukkon capitalists running Rupture Farms and then building up your powers to get revenge on them and free your Mudokon brethren.

The gameplay doesn't disappoint: as would be expected with the game that pretty much launched the Oddworld franchise up there with the other big players at the time. Whilst there's some action elements, like when you're running away from the Slig guards and their hounds or using your psychic powers to make your enemies brutally massacre each other, it's really a puzzle game at heart. The protagonist Abe is not a fighter and must rely on his wits and indirect abilities to outsmart a small army as well as the various beasts lurking in the wilderness. You can breeze through the introductory section fairly easy using the basic interaction and stealth skills, but later on when you're doing things like navigating ancient temples you can be ages stuck in small chambers just trying to work out how to get past an obstacle without getting ripped to shreds. 

The visuals hold up as well- it's insane to think that this game is coming up for twenty years old in September. The art style remains gorgeous with a lot of soul and the sprites have nice animations and character. The controls are also relatively decent- it takes a while to get the hang of aspects like sprint-jumping with precision and utilising the throwing mechanic, but once you've tried it a few hundred times you get fairly accurate with it. Something also worth noting is the soundtrack and voice acting, both of which add a lot of the atmosphere and make for fine listening.

All in all, I highly recommend this game. The sequel, Abe's Exoddus, is essentially more of the same with a few added mechanics like being able to control Glukkons or issue more commands to your Mudokon followers- so I'd also recommend that title if you're into this one. There's also a remake of this game floating around, New N' Tasty: it has some good things going for it like HD 3D environments and more Mudokons to save, but honestly I prefer the original because it retains a certain something that the remake just doesn't seem to have. At least for me, anyway.

31952391.review: Very good game and great childhood memories 9/10

31887033.review:
[b]You might like if:[/b] You want to relive your Oddworld days, but lack the PlayStation version. It's a shaky port though, so new players would probably be better off checking out Oddworld: New 'n' Tasty instead (the modern remake), as It likely won't be the same without the nostalgia.

Great game. Naff port.

For the masochistic among us who spent our childhood watching Abe repeatedly get shot/eaten/crushed/fall hilariously down a massive ravine; and yet somehow still save all 99 Mudokons and want to relive that brutality again... 3 things to beware of that haven't translated well from the PlayStation version to PC:

[list]
    [*]Overall game speed is faster (maybe 20%?)... And, as any veteran will tell you, the last thing meat saws need is more oomph...

    [*]Controller mapping is shaky - We've lost the L2/R2 buttons where it doesn't recognise the triggers on most controllers. It's also a sod to configure as well, unless you know which is button 1, 2, 3, 4... Not unworkable, but fiddly and takes some getting used to.

    [*]The game stretches to full screen... which [i]really[/i] doesn't flatter it. I'd personally prefer the option to let it retain its native resolution and run with the black sidebars (akin to the screenshots on the store page).
[/list]

It's a shame the port doesn't do it justice, as the game is an utterly stellar stealth-and-rescue platformer. You're stuck as a slave at the bottom of the food chain and have to escape the clutches of the Magog Cartel before you become their latest ready-meal. Outgunned, you purely have to use your wits to escape. But it gets better... You also have to save your friends too. And so ensues a frustrating Lemmings-like rescue where you have to ensure that [i]they[/i] don't get shot too... or aimlessly walk into a landmine.

You think Dark Souls is brutal? Kid... you ain't seen nothing yet...

But you get the beautiful taste of retaliation too. Play with grenades, use your enemy's own traps against them... or better still, possess them and have them wreak the carnage for you. Play it well and you might even be able to gain enough powers to blast them to ashes...

It's a wonderfully challenging platformer: Requiring as much precision and fast reflexes as it does puzzle solving. It's all about looking at the level you are in and how best to use it to your advantage. It does have a few flaws though (thankfully fixed in its successor, Abe's Exoddus): Whilst you (graciously) have infinite lives and frequent checkpoints, the lack of quick save can make some fiddly areas an absolute ball ache. You also tend to need a strategy guide to find all of the hidden areas, as there aren't any sneaky tell-tale markers you can look out for.

It's just a shame the port is so scrappy. It's not unplayable... but it's certainly hard work, and nostalgia can only get you so far.

My childhood! Extremely fun game but realise that :

THERE IS NO QUICK SAVE IN THIS GAME (the sequel, "Abe's exodus" does have it though). It makes areas extremely difficult as most require precise movements. Checkpoints are common, but the severe difficulty of  each area may make a 30 second segment into a 10-20 minute segment. Also, there are secret areas between checkpoints, which take you to a different level. Once you complete and exit this secret level, you have to get to the next checkpoint without dying, else you have to do the secret area all over again.
All this makes for a very tense, rewarding but extremely frustrating gameplay.
    

These are all the issues i've faced with the steam version and did not experience in the CD version

(1) Cutscenes lag and stutter heavily. There is a fix for it in the forums, but it caused fps loss for me in the actual game. 

(2)Every once in a while an enemy runs off a ledge making the area considerably easier. I've also noticed that the game crashes eventually if youtube is on in the background (not even playing the video), may just be me though.

(3) I experienced issues saving the game. Sometimes the saves go through, sometimes they don't. I cant figure out the reason why.

(4) Gamespeak, is the language you speak to other characters in the game.For example, you press 1 to say "hello" and 2 to say "follow me".  However, you need to hold the button as opposed to pressing the button. If you press (tap the button as you usually do), it starts and prematurely ends the animation before completion. May be a problem for some.

31521951.review:
Esto es el Oddworld, un mundo extraño donde "in-habitan" montones de criaturas fantásticas y especiales. En otro tiempo el Oddworld era un paraíso donde convivían diferentes especies en paz con la naturaleza, pero todo eso cambió cuando llegaron los despiadados Glukkons con su tecnología y su insaciable avaricia. Los Glukkons instalaron fábricas y factorías por todas partes, contaminaron el aire y los bosques, y esclavizaron a las criaturas medianamente inteligentes para que trabajasen en sus oscuros negocios. Y estos fueron los afortunados, pues los menos inteligentes eran directamente tratados como ganado, criándolos en granjas para después descuartizarlos y venderlos por un precio supuestamente razonable. Los esclavos favoritos de los Glukkons eran los Mudokon, unos despreocupados zoquetes que vivían en lo profundo de la selva y eran terriblemente fáciles de engañar y someter. Todo les va de perlas a los malvados Glukkons hasta que se encuentran con un inesperado problema, las especies que llevan décadas masacrando han empezado a extinguirse. Sin carne con la que comerciar, los beneficios bajan, y eso no les gusta nada a los Glukkons. Este giro de los acontecimientos atrapa al pobre Abe por pura casualidad, pues un día este adorable bobalicón se encuentra fregando los suelos próximos a la oficina de su jefe, Molluck el Glukkon, cuando al pasar junto a la puerta escucha como este explica a sus socios el problema de la falta de materias primas y la bajada de beneficios. Pero Molluck no parece preocupado, pues ha encontrado una nueva materia prima con la que trabajar... ¡Los Mudokon! Ahora Abe y toda su especie aparecen en el menú, y si nadie lo impide, toda su raza será diezmada y envasada lista para su inmediato consumo. Las alarmas saltan y Abe es descubierto, los Glukkon no pueden permitirse que sus planes se sepan, pues podría desencadenar una rebelión entre los Mudokon. Abe es ahora su principal objetivo, así que nos tocará a nosotros ayudar a este pobre desgraciado en taparrabos a escapar de las Granjas Hostiles de los Glukkon y a salvar a toda su gente.

Todo este mundo fantástico y especial gira entorno a un negrísimo sentido del humor donde no pararemos de reírnos de situaciones tan dramáticas como que varios de nuestros compañeros acaben hechos puré en una picadora de carne. O ver como Abe se estampa contra el suelo tras caer desde varios pisos de altura. Si hubiese que representar el sentido del humor negro con una imagen, podría hacerse perfectamente con una captura de este juego. De hecho el que no importe que nos maten al contar con vidas infinitas, en más de una ocasión provocará que nosotros mismos hagamos alguna trastada o nos suicidemos de forma cómica solo para estallar en carcajadas. Todo este estilo gamberro y desenfadado le da al juego un toque muy especial que os acompañará de principio a fin.

Como en todo buen juego de plataformas debemos avanzar por el nivel esquivando trampas, agujeros, y demás peligros, pero aquí estamos casi indefensos ante los enemigos, siendo nuestra principal arma nuestra sesera. Prácticamente todo el juego está formado por puzzles, ya que cada escenario presenta un reto en sí mismo. Llegar del punto A, al punto B, en ocasiones requerirá que observemos detenidamente el escenario para evitar caer en una trampa mortal. No debéis preocuparos por el numero de vidas, ya que como decíamos son infinitas, pero no vayáis a pensar ni mucho menos que eso hace el juego fácil. Ya simplemente avanzar supondrá un reto importante, en el que habrá que demostrar tanto nuestra pericia y reflejos con el mando, como nuestra inteligencia para resolver de la mejor manera posible cada situación.

Pero no olvidéis que vuestra principal misión aquí (además de sobrevivir) es la de salvar a los otros Mudokon, y es aquí donde entra en juego un componente que diferencia a este juego de otros similares. Los propios Mudokon y su disposición en los escenarios, forman parte del puzzle que presenta cada pantalla del juego, no solo deberemos evitar nosotros las trampas y los enemigos, si no que los otros Mudokon también deberán hacerlo. Para ello disponemos de un sistema verbal que nos permite comunicarnos con estas y otras criaturas mediante órdenes sencillas del tipo "sígueme", o "espera". Pero antes de nada hay que ser educado y saludar, así que si vemos otro Mudokon lo primero será saludarle diciéndole "hola", y después podemos pedirle que nos siga. Para salvarlos, deberemos llevarlos hasta un portal que se activa cuando Abe realiza su canto ceremonial, pero no será tarea sencilla, pues por el camino deberemos evitar guardias y peligros.
Si nos matan a un Mudokon, o sentimos que de algún modo la hemos pifiado, podemos "suicidar" a Abe y volver así al último punto de control para repetir esta zona. Al contar con vidas infinitas podemos permitirnos este método de ensayo y error, sistema que por cierto vicia bastante. En este punto quizá toque lamentar algo negativo, y es el sistema de guardado, sistema que fue mejorado en entregas posteriores pero que aquí se hace algo farragoso, principalmente por lo lento del proceso mientras la consola lee la tarjeta de memoria y elegimos donde guardar. Además no se guardará el progreso en el último checkpoint que hayamos pasado, si no que el sistema de guardado utiliza otros checkpoints más ocasionales, lo que puede provocar que nos toque repetir una zona anterior que ya habíamos superado cuando carguemos nuestra partida.

Por suerte no estamos totalmente indefensos, pues el canto de Abe también tienen la capacidad de poseer algunas criaturas para que las manejemos a distancia. Si uno de los guardias, llamados Slig, nos estorba en el camino, podremos poseerlo y manejarlo para aprovecharnos de sus habilidades, por ejemplo disparando su ametralladora para despachar otros guardias, o haciendo que se estrelle contra una mina explosiva que nos molesta el paso. Pero no siempre podremos hacer esto, ya que en algunos escenarios habrá dispuestos orbes de seguridad que nos lanzaran un rayo si nos ven cantar, de modo que tendremos que buscar otras soluciones. La forma de resolver cada puzzle no es siempre definida, y se nos da libertad para que busquemos nuestras propias formas de resolver cada problema.

¡Salva a los Mudokon! O no...
No todo el juego será salvar Mudokons, también habrá zonas en las que simplemente habrá que superar retos de habilidad y plataformeo, por ejemplo mientras huimos de un enemigo. Todo el juego está compuesto de momentos tranquilos de pensar entremezclados con otros de tensión donde serán importantes los reflejos, esto le da al juego una mezcla especial que lo hace más ameno y variado. También encontraremos zonas ocultas dentro de los niveles que suelen esconder Mudokons en su interior, en total hay 99 Mudokon esparcidos por el juego, y muchos de ellos están escondidos en estas zonas secretas, de modo que si queremos superar el reto de salvarlos a todos habrá que dedicarle muchas horas al juego y explorar cada rincón. No obstante tampoco será necesario salvarlos a todos para completar la aventura, pero cuantos más salvemos pues mejor claro.

Gráficamente el juego es una delicia, lo era en 1997 y lo sigue siendo hoy en día.

Recomendadísimo este clásico: 10/10

30571942.review:
Never been a PS man myself, making this playthrough of Oddworld my first. Judging from what I've read, I think our situation here is a terrible port of an excellent game.

The positives:
-Interesting and thought-provoking puzzles
-While meager, a fun world, sense of humor and plot
-Cool art design, yo

The negatives:
-Abysmal controls. Controlling Abe as he runs, jumps, walks slowly, rolls, mounts creatures and communicates with other characters is so blocky and obtuse to the point of aggravation. I know exactly what I want Abe to do. Translating that to the mechanics of the controls was excrutiating.
-Frame rate in the cut scenes (excellent for the 90's!) is bested by old Gumby claymation. I can hardly tell what's going on in cutscenes with all the tearing.
-Saving system is unclear. I can save at any point, but there's no telling where I will end up when I load a file. I may end up seven zones back from where I left off. I can lose up to half an hour of progress thanks to inaccurate saving.
-Several times I loaded save files without Abe. I was stuck on a screen with no playable character. Rebooting the game fixed this but geez.
-For the love of God why isn't there any controller support for Oddworld? This is killer on my hands trying to play this on my laptop keyboard! Why would a game designed for a controller not receive controller functionality during its port?
-This game caused one of my laptops to crash whenever I tried loading it.

I don't recommend this particular port. That is, assuming that your experience on your machine will be anything like mine. I wish I could play this game as it was originally designed. I can just imagine how excellent a playable Oddworld would be.

FULL DISCLOSURE: I received this product for free during a special free download day a while ago.

30302766.review:
To start, the story behind the game is clear and simple and is explained well enough in the intro cinematic. Oddworld is a world where corporations run by a race of aliens known as Glukkons, seek to gain huge profits through the exploitation of the environment, native wildlife and most importantly, the subjugation of other species as slaves.

What I liked in the game:
	- Story: The reason why I like the story behind this game so much is because its engaging. As a player you immediately see that what the corporations are doing is immoral and has to be stopped. The other side to the game is its crude humour aspect, where if the player decides they have no interest in the problems of Oddworld, they can still enjoy the game either through the simple challenge of the puzzles or mindless violence, usually involving meat grinders.
	- Challenging: This game is hard, not impossible, but hard. The game has received many criticisms because of this aspect but in this review I see the difficulty as a good thing. It challenges the player to try different strategies. Sometimes patience is the best way to complete a puzzle, others its easier just to run through and hope for the best. Either way, the game rewards the player for completing challenging areas with… another, harder area. This pushes the player to get better and better or else they won't be able to complete the game, this gives the player incredible satisfaction when the complete an area and gives them a boost of confidence in the face of the next.
	- Excellent Art Style: Yes, this is an old game and the graphics are not by any means HD but, still the game remains an inspiration for me. One of the most notable features is how the game plays with both the foreground and background adding another level of depth to the game.
	- Soundtrack: The soundtrack is simple and engaging. Alarms sound, intense music plays and enemies chase you through halls and jungles and when you make a mistake and lose the chase, there's the music again to remind you of your failure.
What I didn't like in the game:
	- Save points: This is a big problem with this game. You can only save your game at certain save points and these can be fairly far apart from each other. There is no quicksave feature and no autosave leading to the occasion repetitive experience of failing to complete an area over and over again.
	- PC Version: This is a review of the PC version and not for either the original PSX/PS1 game or New and Tasty (The HD remaster). I want to start by saying I do not enjoy this game as much on the PC. The controller took a little while to map to the original controls and after that I was still having problems with using the analog sticks of my xbox 360 controller instead of the dpad. This lead to me moving one too many tiles forward or back resulting in a fast death either from falling or from electric fence. The keyboard controls aren't as bad as I thought however, as you progress through the levels they get faster and faster. I found myself fumbling around the keyboard pressing the wrong buttons. This is probably not a huge problem for gamers who use their keyboards frequently.
Overall, I love this game. It has its problems yes but you learn to adapt to those making the game even more unique. I give Oddworld: Abe's Odysee a clear 9/10.

30165580.review:
I remembered about the Oddword series recently and knew that I was too young and dumb to ever finish it. I liked the fact that you could fart and also I had a PS2 from a friend with no memory card.

Thus, I really wanted to play and see what the game is all about.

I'm finding hard to believe that this game was released in 1997 and that I chose to play this game when I missed on a lot of other modern games, but the reasons strenghten my decision. 

The lore is intriguing and the characters are funny and in combination with the artistic direction it offers you a friendly, mysterious, dark and constantly a dangerous environment.

Most of the time I found the game very challenging, in 3 situations I had to check for solutions on YouTube or a written walkthrough. This game is not giving you constant and obvious hints, if you don't pay attention to the environment and don't read thoroughly the promped texts you will find yourself clueless and you get frustrated. Also, the control of the character is going to punish you if you make a single additional step in certain situations, so you have to be very coordinated and disciplined in order to pass certain sections of the game.

Game mechanics are smart and unique, considering when this game was released, generating puzzles that do not feel repetitive and putting your brain to use. I didn't play more than 1 hour constantly because I got frustrated and felt the need to take a break, that's how challenging I found this game to be.

This game is also aiming to test your personality and how much you are willing to sacrifice for the greater good, but I'm not going to talk about this. There's so much I'd like to write so that I highly praise this iconic game that everybody should experience.

28531211.review:
I don't know what to make of this game. The game has some really good puzzles to get through but it is at the same time it is so infuriating to get through.

When the game sets itself into small micro levels (such as the trails or zulag rooms) then the game is fun to get through where it gives you a decent checkpoint and a set of objectvies to complete to get through the area. Where you can easily try and complete the puzzles put before you. The limitations of the area which you need to transcend lets the game to florish.

Unfortnately the game falls apart in the more larger levels. This mainly down to the extremly poor checkpoint system. The checkpointing system is too sparse and any bonus you do will not create a new checkpoint after completion so you end having to re do any bonus area if you die and this can make sections last alot longer then needed and it becomes infurtiating that you have to constantly have to recomplete large sections of the game to proceed.

Another problem is the hit detection and platforming sections of the game. When sections of the game demand precise platform is where the worst parts of the game shows up. You can be hurt by jumping obstacles by just standing on the edge of the platform which is extremly annoying considering the one hit kills in this game. The game also demands extremly precise platforming that you can easily miss the jump. This is also not helped by slow turning movements and unresponsive controls.

The AI is also annoying as you try to get it to do something specific and it ends up doing something else entirely.

Overall This game was infuriating to play but when it slowed down and placed into much tighter and smaller areas the game really shines but it doesn't make up for the rest of the game.

27908846.review:
Having extensively played the PS1 original and fully completed the PC port version of this absolute masterpiece of a game, I can safely say that this is perhaps the worst PC port of any game that I have ever come across.

Pay no attention to my playtime, I completed this while my net was down.

The controls are even blockier and less responsive than on PS1. Naturally, this comes with the platform but somehow this PC port manages to worsen the issue. You're left having to press 2 five or six times to tell your friends to follow you, as much of the time nothing whatsoever happens when you attempt to do so. You will often kill yourself not due to your own personal error but because you have simply kept going when you've stopped pressing your movement keys. This is particularly frustrating when you're [spoiler] disarming bombs [/spoiler], due to the precision needed. 

Next, cutscenes. For whatever reason, every single cutscene and animation in the game, including the [b] startup animations [/b], are limited to a literal frame per second. Again, originally being a PS1 game obviously would place limits on framerate but you'd expect for a PC port to increase framerates, not the exact opposite. What were memorable and important moments in the game on PS1 are now frustrating and unwelcome breaks in the already blocky play of this port. Only actual gameplay runs semi-respectably.

My only quall with the original PS1 version was the saving system and, you guessed it, this port makes absolutely no effort to rectify the problems. You can save anywhere, anytime, however you are almost guaranteed to pick up the game again in an entirely different spot to where you saved. We aren't talking ages back, more a couple of rooms or puzzles back from where you were, but this is frustrating nonetheless- I've personally lost up to ten minutes of progress from an awful save system.

Finally, we reach the biggest problem. The one aspect that makes this port absolutely unforgiveable.
The ending. It isn't the same.
I spent hours working out how to successfully save all 99 of your mudokon friends, as I was never able to complete this when I was younger. The last one jumps into the portal, and I'm expecting to get some sort of special cutscene or something, a reward for full completion.

I get a message, telling me that I cannot actually see the content that I would have seen, due to recommendations from their lawyers. Instead, I get a list of the cutscenes that I've already seen, and of course, they don't load.


Abe's Oddysee is an incredible game, a real classic of the PS1 era.
This port destroys it, and it does downplay the great memories I had trying to complete it when I was younger.
Play the PS1 version.

And it has some of the most iconic villains and enemies to date!

Definitely a recommendation for people who enjoy this genre, even if it's just for the remake "New'n'Tasty".
For this price it is listed with, it's actually a must-buy.

27224280.review:
I have first played a demo on this game on PlayStation on December 6th 1998, as an 8-year old scrub, not knowing enough english to understand anything aside from Game Speak, and yet I immediately fell in love with it. So much, that for Christmas in the same year I got the full version, in German so I didn't understand the plot AT ALL. But, the gameplay, that was something else. This was probably the first game of this type where you could interact with characters in such a way (giving them commands), and I'm not entirely sure if anything other than Oddworld series did that. The game is also very hard, but in a good way (think like Dark Souls - challenging, but fair, and the moment you beat a hard segment? Pure satisfaction).

Now go forward a few years, to December 21, 2010. The date OddBox released on Steam, containing within two classics, Abe's Oddysee with it's sequel, Exoddus; another game from the series Munch's Oddysee and a spinoff Stranger's Wrath, where the last two were released for the first time outside of original Xbox. It was a must have, and now, knowing english very well, the plot is a masterpiece.

In short, if you are a fan of challenging platforming games and love some dark humor going with a great story, this game is for you.

26825819.review:
Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee es un plataformas de la vieja escuela. Requiere saltos ajustados, buenos reflejos y buena capacidad de análisis para resolver los puzzles que se plantean en cada fase. La curva de dificultad no es demasiado elevada. Tras unos primeros pasos que sirven de tutorial, ya conocemos la mayoría de mecánicas que se usarán en el juego.

Argumentalmente no es un juego demasiado complejo. La mayor parte de la narrativa recae en pequeñas cinemáticas que aparecen a lo largo de la aventura. Aún así, lo mejor de todo es el trasfondo del universo Oddworld, que cuenta con potencial para explicar muchas historias interesantes.

En cuanto a nivel visual, el tiempo le ha pasado algo de factura. Aún así, el juego aguanta el tipo de manera muy digna y cuenta con una gran dirección de arte.

26466360.review:
I have this game on GOG and on Steam and couldn't recommend it highly enough. 
It doesn't suffer from a lot of the issues other games from its time may normally suffer from and the majority of the game has aged very well. I believe it's aged so well because of how far ahead of its time it was and of course, the amount of time and love that was put into it. 

I have beaten this game numerous times on Playstation and I even beat it once with 100% completion, which was no easy task, but it was a lot of fun and more rewarding than achievements in many more modern games.

The political undertones within Abe's Oddysee are by no means subtle but they are done so well and clearly weren't just shoehorned in; this game and its story were all built with meaning everywhere. The message is found within it and not the other way around. 

It's a great message with meaningful characters that could easily have felt generic and certainly could have been more two dimensional like many games at the time. 

Keep in mind - this is before we even touch the surface of the gameplay. 
This game is a work of art in that respect as well. 

The game design is very tightly knit. 
It's so obvious that the developer loved this game and poured hundreds of hours into ensuring it had a fine layer of polish in every aspect of its design. Your motive is clear from a story standpoint and from a gameplay standpoint. You can almost always immediately see what needs to be done and any thought process required for figuring something out always ends with an intutive solution and never leaves you shaking your head in frustration or disbelief. 

This game is incredible and at its price point, it's a crime not to already own it; don't get me started on what I think if you're still wondering if you should buy it. 

I would recommend this to almost everyone but it's certainly not a casual game. 
If you do NOT like difficulty BUT possess patience then I STILL recommend this game to you.
If you don't mind getting stuck and find joy in figuring things out and in continued success in a slightly uphill battle then this game is absolutely for you!

If you think you're a boss at games and that difficulty is something you've no intentions of experiencing then prepare to meet it for the first time. 

This game can be tough but it's a good kind of tough.
You know how a good medium rare steak is utterly delicious but requires you to be paitent and chew it a bit?

Abe's Oddysee puts that steak to shame because it's got even more seasoning, flavor, and doesn't cost $12 dollars for just a few bites of gameplay.

Add this to your library today - unless you're going to play New 'n' Tasty, which DOES include this original as well!

If you need help getting this running correctly then check in the community section or do some googling. 
You just need to a download a config file, open in notepad, make some changes to it and you're on your way! 

It took me about three minutes. 

10/10 from me and I RARELY hand one of those out!

Also - I personally recommend a controller for most platformers and I'm the king of platformers.

25984194.review: One of the greatest games of all time. Can be frustrating playing it now, especially after Exoddus, specifically only being able to speak to one mudokon at a time. But apart from that, gameplay is awesome, Mostly stealth but in it's own unique way, and feels awesome when you get to turn the tables on the enemy. The real reason to play this game though, is the atmosphere. Much like Silent Hill 2, this game is one of the greatest pieces of art due to the amazing atmosphere and feelings it conveys to the player. The Stockyard escape with the planets and stars in the background and that eerie but also peaceful music. The Paramonian temple, dark, creepy and a nightmare to us arachnaphobes everywhere. And Scrabania, the only desert/mountain based level in any game I genuinely like. You feel like you are high af (and I do mean vertically) and you can imagine the immense heat from the landscape. One of the greatest examples of atmosphere done right in any game. You can't really describe atmosphere, so basically just play it and witness it.

A brilliantly weird side-scrolling adventure. Getting through the assorted hazards is tough enough on its own, but you also have a secondary task to consider: rescuing other Mudokons by leading them safely past danger and into magical portals. You're free to ignore them and simply blast through the central challenges, in which case you'll get a shorter experience and a downer ending. Alternatively you can work to save them all, which involves discovering and exploring a lot of trap-filled secret rooms, which is a lot more rewarding.
Great Game from the old days

24313302.review:
A certified, dyed in the wool PS1 classic brought to Steam. Who would've thought it possible?

Now, allow me to tell you all what I know of Abe's Oddysee. If you remember games like Flashback: The Quest For Identity, this game plays something similar to it, only you're playing as a Mudokon named Abe, but you have no weapons, one special skill through possession by way of chanting and only your wits, conversational skills, farting and you must know how to carry a good tune when you hear it. You're working at Rupture Farms, what you thought to be the best place to work in the world. Well, you were really enslaved. But you had to go and cross the meanest boss in the world, Mullok the Glukkon all because you found out that they were looking to make increased profits by killing your buddies and make Mudokon Pops out of them! Now, it's up to you to save yourself and 99 other Mudokons from a terrible fate. But, be warned. One mistake will get you killed either embarrassingly or hilariously, depending on who or what killed you, so you'll have to move carefully as well as quickly.

This is not a task you should take lightly, as there is a consequence if you don't save enough of your buddies. I won't spoil the ending for you, but let's just say that it doesn't end well.

When it comes to controls, it may be a bit wonky if you're using the keyboard, so a controller is a definite must-have. The graphics are indeed old, but for the time this game was released, they're nothing short of remarkable. When it comes to music, this game has some of the best soundtracks that you'll ever hear, whether you're sneaking around a factory, getting chased by Paramites or even exploring a temple.

Now, would I recommend this game? Of course, I would. Given the fact that it's dated as all hell, the simple fact remains the same. I grew up with this game many moons ago when the dinosaurs roamed the earth and it still stands the test of time even now, especially after the release of Oddworld: New 'n Tasty. It may not look as good now as it did long ago plus the AMV's are a bit of a trainwreck to look at, but that can be easily remedied.

But all in all, give this a shot if you want something different from your usual standard fare puzzle-platformer.

23934029.review: Ah, Oddworld: Abe's Oddyssee, a game from my childhood I have very fond memories of. I used to spend hours playing this wonderful game with my dad. I still remember the moment we first found out about the possession skill of Abe and our amazement that followed. The eerie atmosphere combined with relentlessly high difficulty at some points and comic relief at others had left an ever lasting impression in my then game-inexperienced mind. I was more than pleasantly surprised to find the Oddbox, which includes this game, on Steam, if only to relive the many moments which, to some extent, have shaped my perspective on videogames. Of course, the graphics are outdated and the controls may need some getting used to for new players, but this is a videogame I can recommend with my fullest conviction! The action-packed levels, the puzzle-solving and the story of a slave trying to save his kind are things many a gamer will enjoy.

It took me 14 hours to beat this game, and probably 10 of those hours were spent repeating parts I had already finished because this game's checkpoint system is awful.

22903558.review:
I remember buying this game back when it was released for the PlayStation 1. As far as I remember, it was a popular release and it received many positive reviews by the major publications of the time. I was excited to buy it but as soon as I began playing it, I remember being disappointed. I can't remember whether or not I beat it back then but chances are high that I got bored and quit playing just as I did now.

Despite what the multitude of nostalgic, rabid and headstrong fans say, Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee  didn't age well at all from what was already a mediocre effort to begin with. While the character design is interesting and charming, everything else is quite flawed. The background graphics and animations are average to below average, the music is nearly non-existent, the sound effects can get borderline annoying at times, and worst of all, the controls are extremely unresponsive, sluggish and awkward. Getting Abe to perform the most basic of platforming moves such as seamlessly running, stopping, climbing on a ledge and then sneaking is painful and inadequate. Controlling Abe feels very much delayed and as if the movements were restricted in some way. The puzzles and rooms are designed competently for the most part but when you have to deal with the game's awful controls, solving each screen is too aggravating and devoid of any fun whatsoever. The gameplay revolves around traversing the game world one screen at a time. Even though not every screen presents the player with a puzzle or a situation that needs his or her attention, there is still the need to advance through each screen individually and with a slight pause between each transition. Deaths come often and the player will be forced to repeatedly wait through a lengthy death and restart animation that takes about five seconds to complete. The save system is based on checkpoints, so if the player dies several screens beyond the last checkpoint, every screen from the checkpoint to the point of death will need to be redone as many times as it takes until you reach the next checkpoint. Without mentioning any spoilers, it is encouraged that there is at least one additional playthrough after you beat the game once. In relation to this, one of the worst design choices in the game presents itself. The goal is to rescue slaves. Unfortunately for the player, many of the slaves are hidden away in secret areas that are absolutely not easy to find. Thanks to this design decision, this means the player will fail at the goal the game has set to be accomplished.

It's surprising to me how much love Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee has garnered through the years. It has far too many flaws to be enjoyed and it's way too annoying to be played to completion. This game could easily have been so much better than it actually is.

Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is mediocre.

22876644.review:
Intense platforming with a charming funny world and inhabitents.

Fun is ruined by an inconsistent saving system.  Death comes easy and fast but returning to where you died to try again can take a frustratingly long time.  A quick save would have fixed this, but no such option exists.

Designed to be harsh but completely at the expense of fun.  Each death can reset a considerable amount of progress - to the point of being unfair.

The later iterations have fixed this, but this 1997 version has little respect for your time.  I find it impossible to recommend because the genre (punishing game play that teaches through deaths) has been far more refined in modern games.

Claims of this being 'hardcore' or for 'oldschool' players aren't made by those who value their time.
