22845187.review:
While the game's remake is already available on Steam (under the title New 'N' Tasty) you can still pick up the original Oddworld game which was released back in 1997 - almost 20 years ago! This was what started the Oddworld franchise that since that year has seen several sequels.

These games are all about Abe, the titular character, who is a Mudokon slave being captive in a factory. Initially just a worker, but later labelled as "meat to be processed", Abe sets out to escape from his captors and also to free his fellow Mudokons in the process. The game's first cutscene (which is pretty long considering it is an old game) summarises the story very well and we can quickly understand what's ahead of us.

This is a 2D platformer, so we go from screen to screen and every new "room" represents a new challenge. We have patrolling enemies as well as traps and of course members of the Mudokon race who we need to rescue. We can issue some basic commands to them to make sure they follow us - this part where you communicate with the others can be hilarious. 

Do note that this is one of those games where one mistake can lead to certain death. Checkpoints are regularly placed, though, so at least the game is not punishing you for being a little careless from time to time. One particularly interesting thing is how you can make other Mudokons die if you are not careful - the game does not take you back to the last checkpoint so you may think this is not a problem. Truth is, the number of saved Mudokons determines the ending of the game - you can either get the Good or the Bad ending.

The gameplay is really good - Abe can do a lot of things in terms of movement and activating various mechanisms throughout the factory. Sections tend to get more and more difficult but Oddworld offers an acceptable learning curve here. I haven't tried the remake so I do not know how good a job they did - still, if you like old games or you are, just like myself, someone having played this back in the '90s do give it a try once more!

But I still tremendously enjoy the game's atmosphere, story, SFX and voice acting! 21765167.review:
You know those games you got when you were a child and you played the fuck out of them, even when you already beat them? This is one of those games of my childhood, it comes with a major problem, sadly.

1: Checkpoints. Often I will find a secret area, spend 1-15 minutes figuring out how to do it, leave the secret area, die to something and have that 1-15 minutes of progress lost and having to be repeated EACH time you make a mistake until the next checkpoint. You get better and can execute the puzzles faster, but the "secret area" puzzles are generally very difficult. There's one as early on as the first few screens of the game and damn is it frustrating to be forced to redo it each time you die to something entirely unrelated later on. This isn't the kind of game you can just pick up and not make any mistakes, and sticking to the main path the game handles it's saves very well, but you will die, you will come across trial and error moments, and you will lose some progress.

2:Controls: Once you get familiar, or played this game for your entire childhood (oh and use good gamepad) the controls aren't AS big of an issue. They are still an issue, it's just not as awful. There's also very little in the way of explaining some of the more advanced things you can do. You can run into a jump, you can run into a roll, you can throw objects while crouching and in 4 directions, if you tap forward you will take one step no matter what. These aren't really problems for the guy who spent countless hours (no steam time counter on ps1 lol) on the game in his childhood but to new comers I can imagine the controls are a bit frustrating to learn on your own.

The game is great if you don't try to be a completionist and stay on the main storyline and is challenging without being frustrating, but when you start to try to solve the longer/more difficult secret areas later in the game, losing that 1-15 minutes of progress EACH time you have a death to something that would've been hard to predict, it's easy to lose motivation when there is a really out of date save system. I mean cheap deaths or "oh shit, didn't see that coming" moments can be entertaining and I don't even think there's anything wrong with them, but replaying big portions of complex/difficult levels gets tedious for those of us who seek out the extra/secret areas and want to finish them.

That being said, I believe Abe's exodus introduced a quicksave and a ton of other great features. This game's story and world will captivate you, it's gameplay is great, but the checkpoint system and learning curve that come with a completionist mindset are harsh and likely not worth it without the massive nostalgia goggles I have on.

I remember freaking out a lot and getting scared - being just a kid of maybe 7, I used to find the Sligs very scary and creepy with those "super fancy and realistic graphics". I laugh everytime I play the game now and I'm so happy that I can make it into all those areas that used to say "Not open until September 1997". Still one of the best games I've played so far.

Ingenio, humor, buen acompañamiento de sonido y ese algo que lo hace diferente a los demás juegos. Uno de esos juegos que jamás pasará de moda.

20803068.review:
Abe's Oddysee is a masterpiece of satire, dark humour and social commentary. One of the few video games to tackle serious real-world issues, Oddysee shines a darkly comedic yet sickly light on the cruelties of factory farming, as well as the exploitation of native cultures and wildlife by corporate greed. The game deals with the dichotomy of industrial and spiritual world views, and places us into a violent, weird and odd world. Just like our own.

While these meanings and intentions are confirmed and stem from Oddworld's brainchild Lorne Lanning, all of this is likely lost on most of Oddworld's audience. It certainly was lost on me when I played it as a small child. However, Oddworld Inhabitants provided an exciting, intruiging and challenging experience in Oddysee whether or not the meanings were decoded. And later on, when the messages become more prevalent, it simply gives us more to talk about, and furthers the cause of games as effective, communicative art.

Overall, Abe's Oddysee is a great game with a compelling setting and story. Exoddus is a brilliant follow-up, with more of the same. Both highly recommended and unexpectedly intelligent gems.

20425287.review:
Abe's Oddysee is, in my opinion, a masterpiece of a game. From the simple but challenging puzzle based gameplay, to the heady artstyle, to the rich world, to the deep and compelling storyline, Every facet of this game comes together perfectly in a way that stands the test of time in a way few games do.


The premise is simple, you play as Abe, A Mudoken slave worker working for the meat processing facility, Rupture Farms. After farming other species to near extinction in service of profit, The tyrannical Glukkon overlords decide to turn their slave workers into their next New 'n Tasty delight. After learning this, Abe decides to escape and try and save some of his fellow workers along the way. The dark thematic elements of the story juxtaposed with the cutesey artstyle and adorable haiku's narrated by Abe goes hand in hand and works on so many levels. The game gives you a glimpse of this diverse, incongruous world and makes you want to know more about what lays beyond.

The gameplay involves you traversing through 2-D environments, avoiding traps and enemies while also leading your fellow mudoken's to safety. Everything you see in the game is tile based. You press forward once, you move forward one tile. When you jump, you jump three tiles ahead and more when you get a running start, It becomes very easy to look at a room and plot out a safe course through it. The challenge becomes executing these long chain of commands without messing up, it can be quite tense at time, especially in the later stages where you'll be required to complete screen after screen after screen of challenging platforming levels. The controls are so tight that when you do eventually overcome an obstacle, the feeling of satisfaction is immense. It's something that's kept me coming back to this game for over a decade.

Each screen also has a handrawn background. Visually speaking, it hasn't aged well. The story these images tell about the world though stand out just as much. It just takes a little imagination.

While the remake doesn't quite capture the nuance of the platforming the way I'd like, It manages to recapture a lot of the narrative hooks that, well, hooked me and is absolutley worth a shot but nothing can compare to the purity of the original.

20394108.review: This game is hard. Hard and punishing. I love this game for its charm and art but jesus christ if this doesn't give you an aneurysm in the first half an hour by golly you sir/mam are made of what diamons are made of. This is one of the tightest platform games ever created. There are rules for the controls and don't think you can glitch your way into the next area by running up a wall. No sir e bob this platform game is on a grid and as much as I want to complain about how easy it is to muck up a jump because I wasn't on the right tile or I held the arrow key down for too long it was always my fault. This is the type of game that demands multiple play throughs and or complete mastery of the controls within the first one minute. By the time you would normally complete the tutorial you have passed 10% of the games secrets. Ayuda a escapar al Mudokon Abe y a sus semejantes de ser convertidos en el nuevo postre de Rapture Farms, armate de paciencia.. porque la necesitarás después de ser empalado, aplastado, fusilado o devorado por la fauna de Oddworld. Su Remake "New'n'Tasty" ha sido totalmente respetuoso con la obra original, añadiendo además escenarios y personajes totalmente poligonales, alguna dinámica de control algo suavizada y actualizada y nuevos niveles de dificultad (además de la posibilidad de hablar con varios Mudokons a la vez como en su secuela Exodus) No obstante, Abe's Oddysee sigue siendo en definitiva el original, más exigente y auténtico.

Un juego clásico, de una estética peculiar y única. Complejo, desafiante en algunas etapas (más si lo completamos al 100%). Una historia sencilla, con personajes muy bien delimitados pero que tiene lo justo para que te atrape. El ambiente del juego, una mezcla entre lo crudo de una realidad muy desalentadora y lo bizarro de sus protagonistas, cuajan en este juego muy bien. La banda sonora es acotada pero es justa en los momentos de mayor tensión y acción. Los vídeos a lo largo del juego, acompañan y completan una historia sobria. Hay que destacar el gran detalle en los doblajes al español muy bien logrados. En síntesis, un juego por el cual vale la pena jugar por el reto que puede llegar a representar y más que nada por la creatividad y el esmero puestos en cada uno de los escenarios y personajes. Un juego que técnicamente está muy bien construido, teniendo en cuenta que fue lanzado en 1997.

10/10

19864376.review:
This game has a few bugs and odd design choices from being poorly ported.
On controller, controls for 2 of the actions are linked together. run/speak2 and sneak/speak1.  Instead of listing those actions together, they're listed in separate locations.
Navigating the menu is somewhat odd.  Pressing escape to go back is pretty normal, however once it reaches the main menu it actually selects the current menu option (i.e. load or options) instead of either doing nothing or exiting the game.

for me the game crashes when closing, thereby forgetting any changed game settings.
The cutscenes run at ~4 fps. Many people note that the game requires a modification of direct draw in order to fix the issue.

gameplay wise the game has a checkpoint system that makes timing based sections rather annoying.  This is common in older games.  However, dying also results in a respawning animation that takes a few seconds which is a poor design choice.

18284670.review:
Un clásico y uno de los mejores juegos de PSone.

Realmente innovador para la época, tanto en el arte, la ambientación, la jugabilidad y las animaciones. Es un juego que ha quedado en el recuerdo de millones de jugadores. Por algo será. 

Jugarlo casi 20 años después es extraño, pero la ambientación no ha perdido su magia, sigue transmitiendo ese ambiente oscuro de opresión en el que te sientes vulnerable todo el rato.

Es un juego bastante difícil (no como el 97% de los juegos que hay ahora), en ocasiones algo frustrante, pero muy adictivo. 

La única pega es que esta versión para PC tiene las cinemáticas con una calidad baja (aunque hay un parche que lo arregla). También hay que tener en cuenta que fue un juego diseñado para PSone, así que es muy recomendable jugarlo con un mando.

18205764.review:
The game is great, as long as you make no mistakes, ever.

The plot is insanely original, the art design is among the best ever put to screen, and the gameplay was revolutionary at the time.

But, the CONTROLS, and the CHECKPOINT SYSTEM.

Combine fidgety controls compounded with a save system that puts you through 18.5 meatgrinders before granting you ANY respite, and you soon accrue frustration on "I-Wanna-Be-The-Guy" levels, to the point where you just don't care to continue the level, and therefore leave the game in the ultimate state of defeat, where you truly beat the game unequivocally: by not playing it.

I picked this up for free, and that was the perfect price. I'd have been pissed off had I bought it for even the three dollars they're charging now.

The game's a fossil. Leave it buried. The juice isn't worth the squeeze.

18180541.review:
Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee: is a strategy platformer with some unique and interesting gameplay experiences. 

Coming back from my childhood, this game was one of the nostalgia flashbacks. A game my parents used to play while I watched. Now playing it for myself it's a lot more fun and the gameplay is addicting. Seriously the obsatcles in levels are a lot of fun and I feel as though I want to play it every day since I got it. 

Though it can get frustrating at times, can take a while to beat the level and
can be a little overbearing for some players. There are obstacles that will make you panic is you're easily scared: Such as running from enemies in a full on pursuit. The stress rate can get high at times, and even some levels are gut wrenchingly hard and make you wanna slap your computer.

Still this game is probably one of the most unique platformers out there. The player has a choice to save as many Mudokens as they feel: and depending on how many you save at the end of the game, you will be featured with an ending based on how well you did. 

With so many unique ways of going about a level and the amazing cut scenes (although old), this game has it all.

I would reccomend to anyone who's into strategy platformers or just brilliant unique art styled games.

18173947.review:
I'm rating "No" by personal preference. [b] If you have childhood memories of this game, or are into hard games, I will instead recommend. [/b]

[u] Nostalgia factor [/u]: None for me

[u] Controls [/u]: Clunky. Jump is very tricky, and overall needs a bit of a learning curve

[u] Difficulty [/u]: I think I can do with this difficulty if the respawn animation was faster. The frustration doesn't come from dying or failing, but comes from the time I have to waste not doing anything. I'm okay with frequent deaths and trying the same thing over, but with the current animation time, no, let's say I have patience issues.

[u] Story [/u]: My patience issues.. caused me to miss out on the story, which everyone speaks highly of. Reviews with little play time are often taken lightly, but this is the best I could do. It says something, if not about the game, at least about my personality.

[u] Setting and Atmosphere [/u] Very well done, especially for a game released in 1997. The introduction is intriguing. So to repeat myself, if the game's mechanism wasn't testing my patience, it would be a fun game. I can sort of imagine how most people had fun with the game and rated it up.

[u] Music and Art [/u]: Not impressive but good enough. The quirkiness is adorable.

Conclusion:
While each of the following is tolerable or even rewarding, when they're combined . . .
Slippery controls + Difficult + Long waiting time as punishment for death + Restricted save funtion = NO
No matter how marvellous the story is, it would be outweighed by above formula imo.

18173302.review:
I love the Oddworld games, Abe's Oddysee is the first one I have had the chance to play on PC. Abe's  Oddysee is the first Oddworld game released, and the first one I ever played way back on the PlayStation 1. Oddworld games are always filled with dark comedy, the Oddworld games always manage to keep a sense of adventure coupled with a macabre feel that I just love. 

In Abe's Oddysee you play a character named Abe, a Mudokon slave worker who uncovers a nefarious plot that could lead to the death of his people. He sets out on a quest to free them, slowly uncovering more of his Mudokon culture along the way.  Gameplay wise Abe's Oddysee is a 2D platformer filled with puzzles and obstacles to complete or circumvent, but remember the ending is dependent on how well you do.

Overall I would recommend Oddworld games to anyone who is a fan of adventure or puzzle games. Oddworld is one of those series that feels really unique, so you'd be challenged to find something close enough to the Oddworld games.

I've noticed in the community that some people were having FPS issues, or other problems related to the cutscenes. For new players, and those that fail to look for fixes before shouting "bad port", without looking to the community hub first, here are links to two similar fixes, both seeking to accomplish the same thing... use whichever you would like.

http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1765599/

I just would hate to see such an incredible game, one of the best I've ever played, one that is often touted among the best of all time, recieve negative reviews over something so trivial. So if you're here, (and I know a lot more reviews will start pouring in since it's free today). and having issues, before reviewing, stop, try to fix it yourself, then enjoy! 

This game.... what can I say? It's difficult, and not in the "OMG THE ENEMIES ARE SO OP", Dark Souls kind of difficult,(not hating, I love DS), but the Oddworld kind. It has to be experienced. This platform adventure will require serious brain power, and you will need to really try if you want to succeed here... but when you do, it is oh, so satisfying. 16770560.review:
Full disclosure: I started playing this years ago on Steam, abandoned it, then played and fininished it this year on my Vita.

Abe's Oddysee is one of those "classics" that comes with a big asterisk. For the most part it's difficult but fare, with your success coming down to timing, preparation, and patience, making each success all the more satisfying, even I'm still convinced the jump button stops working every now and then just to troll you (that's my excuse and I'm sticking to it). The 2 main problems with it, then, are the fail states and the save system - deaths (which are VERY frequent) are met with prolonged musical cues and delays before starting the levels again, and there's no way of telling just how far back a reloaded saved-game is going to take you.
If you can get over those two major problems, it's definitely worth checking out for the puzzles and interesting world alone. If you can't, I won't blame you.

16671243.review:
I recommend this game because the in game controller configuration works.

Works with Xbox 360 controller (although movement was with the analogue stick)
Works with SNES USB controller

You can assign buttons but not directions for the controller.

The best thing about the controller setup is that it's similar to the PS1, so all of Abe's speaking commands can be done by holding down multiple buttons. No need for a 20 button controller.

15867590.review:
A nice blast from the past. I remember never finishing this many moons ago. Thought I would try again. I still very much enjoy the novelty of the game and the nice graphics.

Trouble is, it's still very unforgiving and very frustrating in parts. Though those things are ok as that's just part of a good platformer. The thing I really don't like about the game is all the cheap deaths you incur. Some are there I'm sure, just so you can't do a level in one go. Pull a lever to bring down a lift and a slig pops up and creams you. Or you just go from one screen to the next and suddenly a slog  jumps in from behind you and kills you. Hard, fair games I enjoy and will battle on with. Games that make you do repeat screens because of cheap tricks turns me off.

Thankfully, Abe's Oddysee has much to like about it but it doesn't fully compensate for the cheap tricks. Then comes the ending. This is the cheapest trick of all. ++++ spoiler alert +++ but read it anyway if you want to keep your sanity! So you battle all through the game. 26hrs of it (for me at least). You get to the end, only to be fed into the grinding machine because you didn't happen to save enough Mudokons!!! Up pops a smarta@@ sign saying blah, blah do it again you need to save at least 50 Mudokons. With that, I quit the game and will never go back to it. Just another example of a good game ruined. Why not give us that detail to begin with? Would simply have added another dimension to the game. But no, the old cheap tricks prevail. 

I have marked this as recommended, but it is with reservation that I do. I just wish I knew about the 50 limit when I started. Either that, or I wish I had blown up and splatted every Mudokon I saw. The worst part, was that I did actually try to save every Mudokon I came across and didn't give any a cheap death. Maybe I should play it again just so I can see Mudokon bits flying everwhere bwahahahaha.

While having excellent story, world and artwork, the game itself is extremely hard. You have to be 100% perfect about your timing, character location and movement, otherwise you will be dead. The game has zero tolerance for player's mistakes. Big part of the game difficulty is added by that weird checkpoint system which made you to go through the same screens again and again and make the same actions again and again, until you're dead and have to go through all those damn screens one more time. 
It's a shame it doesn't have a quicksave system, which would greatly improve player's experience and lower frustration. I see now why people usually recommend to play this game using the PS1 emulator which has the save system implemented.
What's more to say? Just download the demo and try it for yourself. If you're patient and skillfull enough that game could be quite exciting. But for me... well, I beat Dark Souls, which is not the easisest game in the world, but Abe got on my nerves so much, that I had to quit playing,

14197448.review:
A great old time game with great amount of challenge that ( [b]in my opinion[/b] ) could even match that of [i]Dark Souls[/i], as this games puzzles and challenges can be unforgiving, punishing you for failing by making you repeat difficult and tedious parts after each death unless there is a checkpoint or you manage to reach one.

Personally, for a game that dates back to 1997, its graphics aren't half bad - although for me, graphics don't make a game.
The difficulity in this game feels a bit "zig zaggy", meaning that it changes from easy to hard to easy to hard and at some points of the game it especially feels like so, where one puzzle is easily solved in a moment, but the following one can be difficult and tedious.

Also, I've already twice come across ILS ( Infinite Loading Screen ) problem, where on the first time I lost my 3 hours of progress due to not having saved - and not expecting this problem to even occur in this game - and second one not too long ago since writing this review. I don't know if it's just me or if anyone else might have this problem occur.

Despite its scale of difficulity, its sometimes tedious puzzles and the mentioned ILS problem, I truly love this game, for both nostalgia reasons - as I used to play this when I was young - and for the fact that I find it fun in general.

Would I recommend this game? Yes! Definately! If difficult, puzzle platformers are to your liking. Or if you are curious about it overall, then I do recommend to check it out.

14057710.review:
This game is a huge part of my childhood, along with Abe's Exoddus. It is a flawless classic with a compelling story and immersive gameplay. The first time you watch the opening cutscene, you know what you've put yourself into. In this game you play as a Mudokon named Abe, who works at the biggest meat processing plant on Oddworld called RuptureFarms. The goal is to help Abe save all 99, if not at least 50 Mudokons throughout your journey after he finds out that Molluck the Glukkon, the CEO of RuptureFarms 1029, wants to chop up you and your pals into tasty treats after beginning to lose profit due to the endangerment of wildlife they're capturing.

While travelling through the eerie and atmospheric domains of Oddworld, you'll encounter various "odd" looking creatures that will make you scratch your head and affect your progression. Each enemy type requires specfic strategizing and tactics to avoid them and reach certain areas in order to get to another. It really keeps you on your toes throughout the whole game. However it's not just the creatures that arouse your curiosity or interest, but also the terrain and landscapes they inhabit. From the dirty, bloody steampunk factory of RuptureFarms, to the native, green forests of Paramonia and the scorching desert of Scrabania, you really feel these environments as you continue your quest to save your fellow Mudokons and free yourself from the hands of the upper class management.  

Oddworld is basically a reflection of our societies problems and the day-to-day issues we regularly face. The reflections of our problems present in the game would be the bad side of consumerism, economics, capitalism, racism, prejudice, pollution etc. Many of these things you will instantly notice in the opening cutscene.

To conclude, this game is an oldschool gem that will remain a huge inspiration for me personally and a fantastic game that has aged well over the past 20 years, in my opinion. Please do yourself a favour and buy this game. It has plenty of originality and a fable that will keep you involved for hours.

My verdict - 9/10.

Plataformas 2D, original y divertido como pocos, un gran diseño para la epoca. Juego de culto dentro del genero, para mi juego fetiche que tiene todas las caracteristicas necesarias de un plataformas old school en dos dimensiones con scroll lateral. Risas, silbidos, flatulencias, mudokons... Una mision mesiánica, salvar a tu especie. Disfruta del universo Oddworld.
Recomendado 100%

13774080.review:
oddworld abe's oddysee is one of the greatest games ever created on the PS1 console. the cut scenes are amazing (even for the 90's these are pretty high class videos)

GAMEPLAY-
this games plays really well, the controls are amazing on keyboard, albeit a tad confusing. BUT not to worry, if you have a playstation game pad for the PC you can hook it up and play this game to your hearts content ... well ... you could do it already if you have a keyboard, but this game is made with a controller in mind so it would only improve on this already fantastic game. 
not to mention how you save game, just pause and save and you're done ... come back when you've decided you won't rage quit over how challenging the game is ... forgot to mention that actually. This game is incredibly unforgiving. one wrong move and "BOOM" ... you're blue paste gets splattered all over the screen, and you're left to think about what would happen to your green comrades if you could not re-spawn ... a banjo kazooie 'quit game ending if you will.

it doesn't do that, i'm just saying thinking about it is weird ... what if they all get eaten and they sell your organs for dog food, humanity goes into a downward spiral as events you couldn't stop, happen. The sequels always end with the sad ending, and you're no where to be seen because you died 2 games ago, nobody even knows your name anymore. As a slag (animal) begins to munch on your tinned mudoken fingers and eyeballs, the last sentient part of you is converted into fecal matter and your race DIES ... all because you took one step to the right and got crushed by a barrel of meat ... but i digress

STORY-
the story to this game is essentially one giant Eco friendly metaphor for our own industrial prowess ... but it is so subtle/just plain ignorable that it will not rest on your conscience at all. basically you're an actual "skrub" worker in the biggest meat factory on odd-world, your bosses want to kill and sell your race to (possibly) unwary, cannibalistic consumers (it's never specified who actually buys all this food). you get found out, chase scene happens, voodoo hoodoo guy with funny mask gives you powers, and you basically take off from there. the story is a lot more in-depth than that but, meh. it would spoil a lot of the lot to go into full detail (I'M DOING THIS FOR YOU, THE PURCHASER OF THIS FINE PRODUCT! DON'T HATE ME!)

GRAPHICS-
It's a ps1 game, so you can expect some ... aging, to take place. it's a side scroller from the 90's so its 32 bit graphic style will always hold up pretty well (if you're a forgiving sort of person who enjoys game play over graphics). it's not the worst game you will ever see in your life ... it definitely gives some 3D games i know of a run for there money.

OVERALL-
i would definitely recommend that you buy this game, as a matter of fact, just buy the entire Oddbox bundle. you get all the Odd-world games for £6.99 (when not on sale). that is a steal for anyone's library as they are all definitely worth purchasing. strangers wrath although not as popular as other Odd-world title is definitely commendable for a referral as well.
